meanings.definition: the male or female sex, or the state of being either male or female:

meanings.definition: the divisions, usually masculine, feminine, and neuter, into which nouns are separated in some languages:

meanings.definition: the condition of being either male or female:

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who dresses or behaves in a way that is not considered typical of their gender:

meanings.definition: unfair difference in the way women and men are treated:

meanings.definition: the act of treating a person, usually a woman, unfairly because of their sex:

meanings.definition: a difference between the way men and women are treated in society, or between what men and women do and achieve:

meanings.definition: the fact of being, or deep feeling that you are, a particular gender:

to make a general statement that something is true in all cases, based on what is true in some cases:
examples: You can't generalize about a continent as varied as Europe.
It's difficult to generalize, but most babies can say a few words by the age of 12 months.
Dr Meyer warned against generalizing the results to populations not included in the study.

meanings.definition: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of him, her, or it:
examples: Your health is generally good, but you do have a few minor problems.
He wants more money to be given to the arts generally.
I shall now develop my previous point more generally (= to say more about what it includes).

meanings.definition: usually, or in most situations:
examples: The baby generally wakes up three times during the night.
Well, generally speaking (= in most situations), it's quicker on public transport.

meanings.definition: by most people, or to most people:
examples: It was generally believed at the time that both men were guilty.
The proposal has received a generally favourable reaction.

meanings.definition: in a way that includes most people, things, or conditions, or most of the time:
examples: It was generally believed at the time that both men were guilty.
The baby generally (= usually) wakes up twice during the night.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         GAAP
the set of characteristics that make a good general (= an officer of very high rank, especially in the army):
examples: The side with superior generalship and majority force would usually win.

meanings.definition: the position or fact of being a general:
examples: President Lincoln’s appointment of politicians to generalships was more sensible than previously thought.

meanings.definition: to cause something to exist:

meanings.definition: to produce energy in a particular form:

meanings.definition: to cause to exist; produce:

meanings.definition: to produce energy:
examples: The wind farm may be able to generate enough power for 2000 homes.

meanings.definition: a factory where electricity is produced:
examples: All of our energy comes from a wind-powered generating station.

meanings.definition: all the people of about the same age within a society or within a particular family:
examples: The younger generation smokes less than their parents did.
There were at least three generations - grandparents, parents and children - at the wedding.
It's our duty to preserve the planet for future generations.
This painting has been in the family for generations.

meanings.definition: a period of about 25 to 30 years, in which most human babies become adults and have their own children:
examples: A generation ago, home computers were virtually unknown.

meanings.definition: all the living things in a group that are born or start to exist at about the same time, and are related to one that existed at an earlier point in time:
examples: The cubs represent the third generation of tigers that have been given radio collars for the project.
Generations of fish and other marine life were compromised because of the oil spill.
Targeted plant breeding can produce promising results within just a few crop generations.

meanings.definition: the production of energy in a particular form:
examples: electricity generation from wind and wave power

meanings.definition: the action of causing something to exist:
examples: There is a carefully planned generation of excitement surrounding each software release.
Law enforcement should focus on public safety, rather than on revenue generation.

meanings.definition: a group of products or machines that are all at the same stage of development:
examples: a new generation of low-fat margarines
Scientists are working on developing the next generation of supercomputers.

meanings.definition: all the people of about the same age within a society or within a particular family, or the usual period of time from a person’s birth to the birth of his or her children:
examples: the last/next generation
There were three generations at the wedding – grandparents, parents, and children.
This farm has been in the family for generations.

meanings.definition: A generation is also a group of products or machines that are all at the same stage of development:
examples: a new generation of cancer drugs
third-generation computers

meanings.definition: (of living things) the act or process of reproducing
a group of people who are about the same age within a society or within a particular family:
examples: Family-owned private firms don't usually aim to sell off the business; they pass it on to the next generation.
the older/younger generation

meanings.definition: the production of energy in a particular form:
examples: electricity/power generation
Electricity generation from coalmine methane offers new employment opportunities as well as environmental gains.

meanings.definition: the process of producing something that will create a profit, income, jobs, etc.:
examples: Traditional rentals are in decline and must be managed to maximise cash generation.

meanings.definition: a group of products or machines that are all at the same stage of development
a way of referring to the group of people who were born in the 1960s and 1970s:
examples: Members of Generation X are often portrayed as having no clear direction to their lives.

meanings.definition: the people born in the US in the second half of the 1960s or the early part of the 1970s
the group of people who were born in the US in the 1960s and 1970s, who, as they became adults, were described as not feeling part of modern society:
examples: Generation X workers are more likely than baby boomers to say they put family before jobs.

meanings.definition: a way of referring to the group of people who were born in the 1980s and early 1990s:
examples: Generation Y, the baby-boomers' children, were more adept than their parents with emerging technology.
He became a fashion idol for Generation Y.

meanings.definition: the group of people who were born in the US and Western Europe in the 1980s and early 1990s, who are the first group to become adults using the internet, and who hope to have a good work-life balance (= the amount of time you spend doing your job compared with the amount of time you spend with your family and doing things you enjoy):
examples: Generation Y, the baby boomers' children, will be the most adept ever with emerging technology.

meanings.definition: a way of referring to the group of people who were born in the late 1990s and early 2000s:
examples: Generation Z has little memory of anything before September 11 2001 and the war on terror.

meanings.definition: the group of people who were born in the US and Western Europe after 2001:
examples: Generation Z has been called as the 'Silent Generation' because of the time they will spend online.

meanings.definition: relating to different generations (= groups of people or members of a family who are around the same age):
examples: Reactions to the changes seem to reflect a generational divide.
A generational shift is taking place as newer, younger business leaders emerge.
These social events aim to help bridge the generational rift/split/gap within communities.

meanings.definition: the belief that people from a particular generation (= a group of people born during the same period of time) share particular characteristics that make them different from, especially better or worse than, other generations:
examples: Generationalism can be seen as a kind of socially approved ageism that has the potential to negatively affect all people, young and old.
When we believe somebody’s age determines how they will behave in the workplace, that is generationalism, which I would argue is both counter-productive and wrong.

meanings.definition: showing the belief that people from a particular generation (= a group of people born during the same period of time) share particular characteristics that make them different from, especially better or worse than, other generations:
examples: Generationalist thinking is persistent in its popularity.
His opinion that the journal should not publish writers aged over 45 is as ridiculous as any generationalist argument.

meanings.definition: a person who believes that people from a particular generation (= a group of people born during the same period of time) share particular characteristics that make them different from, especially better or worse than, other generations:
examples: Generationalists are likely to treat members of different generations differently, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the experiences of particular generations (= all the people of about the same age within a society or within a particular family), or the knowledge and behaviour that older generations teach to younger ones:
examples: These stories are passed down generationally through family folklore.
The generationally specific lifetime experiences of the older people tended to determine their character.

meanings.definition: able to produce or create something:
examples: the generative power of the mind

meanings.definition: able to produce or create something:
examples: Analysts say the business is strongly cash generative and has a solid business model.

meanings.definition: the use or study of artificial intelligences (= computer systems that have some of the qualities that a human brain has, such as the ability to interpret language, recognize images, and learn from data supplied to them) that are able to produce text, images, etc.:
examples: The tech industry rushed to incorporate generative AI into everything from search engines to food delivery apps.
Universities have drawn up new guidelines to help teaching and assessment methods adapt to the growing use of generative artificial intelligence.

meanings.definition: a particular artificial intelligence (= a computer system that has some of the qualities that a human brain has, such as the ability to interpret language, recognize images, and learn from data supplied to it) that is able to produce text, images, etc.:
examples: You can help the generative AI to produce the results you want by giving it more detailed prompts.
Large language models are not the only generative AIs – you have probably also used image generation models.

meanings.definition: the quality of being able to produce or create something new:

meanings.definition: a machine that produces electrical power:

meanings.definition: a machine or device that produces something:

meanings.definition: a company or organization that produces something:

meanings.definition: a person who produces something:

meanings.definition: a machine that produces electricity

meanings.definition: a person, company, government, etc. that produces something:

meanings.definition: a company that produces electricity:

meanings.definition: shared by, typical of, or relating to a whole group of similar things, rather than to any particular thing:

meanings.definition: generic drugs or other products do not have a trademark and are sold without the name of the company that produced them
a product, especially a drug, that is no longer owned or legally controlled by a particular company:

meanings.definition: relating to or shared by a whole group of similar things; not specific to any particular thing:

meanings.definition: Generic also means not having a trademark:

meanings.definition: a product, esp. a drug, that is no longer owned or legally controlled by a particular company:

meanings.definition: shared by, typical of, or relating to a whole group of similar things, rather than to any particular thing:

meanings.definition: relating to the biological process by which the characteristics of living things are passed from parents to children
the arrangement of genes that controls the development of characteristics and qualities in a living thing

examples: Each canvas was layered with two coats of gesso and painted with watered acrylic.
It's a male torso done in pencil on white gesso.
Many antique looking-glass frames are made of wood with gilded gesso mouldings.

meanings.definition: something such as a structure or experience that, when considered as a whole, has qualities that are more than the total of all its parts:
examples: This new biography is the first to consider fully the writer's gestalt.

meanings.definition: considering or treating what a person experiences and believes as a whole and separate thing:
examples: In gestalt psychology and gestalt psychotherapy, people's thoughts and emotions are seen as complex wholes.

meanings.definition: someone who supports the theory that an experience or a belief is a whole and separate thing, and more than the total of its individual parts or characteristics:
examples: Some scholars have argued that gestaltists shared this view, particularly in their account of experience as a single systemic whole.
This is the "aha!" moment of the Gestaltists.

meanings.definition: based on the idea that an experience or a belief is a whole and separate thing, and more than the total of its individual parts or characteristics:
examples: This approach is clearly gestaltist.
There is a distinction between the Gestaltist view and his own views of perception.

meanings.definition: (of a female animal) to have a baby developing inside the body or (of a child or young animal) to develop inside a mother's body:
examples: Female elephants gestate for a staggering 22 months.
healthy foetuses that have gestated at least 20 weeks
Those snakes are often females, soaking up the sun to help their metabolism deal with the demand of gestating a litter of young.

meanings.definition: (of an idea, thought, or plan) to develop or be developed over time:
examples: The internet had been gestating since the fifties.
The subconscious mind needs time to gestate the work.

meanings.definition: (the period of) the development of a child or young animal while it is still inside its mother's body:
examples: The baby was born prematurely at 28 weeks gestation.
The period of gestation of rats is 21 days.

meanings.definition: (the period of) the development of ideas, thoughts, or plans:
examples: The project had a very long gestation period.

meanings.definition: (the period of) the development of a child or young animal inside its mother’s uterus:
examples: The gestation period of rats is 21 days.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a disease or condition that affects pregnant women:
examples: As many as 5% of pregnant women experience gestational diabetes.

meanings.definition: relating to the development of a child or young animal while it is still inside its mother's body:
examples: Rabbits have a 30-day gestational period.

meanings.definition: to make movements with your hands or arms, to express something or to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: There was a man outside the window gesticulating wildly.

meanings.definition: to make movements with your hands or arms, esp. to help express something when you are speaking

past simple and past participle of 
        
         gesticulate
to make movements with your hands or arms, to express something or to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: There was a man outside the window gesticulating wildly.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         gesticulate
to make movements with your hands or arms, to express something or to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: There was a man outside the window gesticulating wildly.

meanings.definition: movements with your hands or arms intended to express something or to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: She was waving her hands in excited gesticulations.
The jokes are told with so much gesticulation that the actors seem to be performing in some kind of new sign language.

meanings.definition: relating to movements, especially when these express ideas or feelings:
examples: Some of the children spontaneously gave a verbal or gestural response.
The violinist is a vividly gestural performer, articulating the shape of phrases as much with her body as with her bow.

meanings.definition: relating to actions that express feelings or intentions, although they might have little practical effect:
examples: This case is just another example of gestural cultural politics.
This election is evidence of how politics is becoming gestural.

meanings.definition: relating to a style of art that is abstract (= representing the idea of something rather than its physical appearance) and is painted with large, free movements rather than small, controlled movements:
examples: From then on his art was characterized by its expansive scale, gestural brushwork, and rich, exuberant palette.
There were echoes of postwar and contemporary gestural abstraction.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves movements, especially when these express ideas or feelings:
examples: Direct speech may be signalled gesturally by air quotes.
The conductor is a gifted communicator, verbally and gesturally coaxing the best from his musicians.

meanings.definition: a movement of the hands, arms, or head, etc. to express an idea or feeling:
examples: The prisoner raised his fist in a gesture of defiance as he was led out of the courtroom.
She made a rude gesture at the other driver.

meanings.definition: an action that expresses your feelings or intentions, although it might have little practical effect:
examples: The government donated £500,000 as a gesture of goodwill.
Eating boiled potatoes instead of chips was his only gesture towards healthy eating.

meanings.definition: to use a gesture to express or emphasize something:
examples: When he asked where the children were, she gestured vaguely in the direction of the beach.
He made no answer but walked on, gesturing for me to follow.

meanings.definition: a movement of the body, hands, arms, or head to express an idea or feeling:
examples: He made a rude gesture to the crowd after his tennis match.

meanings.definition: an action that expresses your feelings or intentions, although it might have little practical effect:
examples: Her warm thank-you note was a nice gesture.

meanings.definition: a simple, quickly made drawing that shows the position or movements of a body:
examples: I made a quick gesture drawing of the pose.

meanings.definition: any action by a person or organization done for political reasons and intended to attract public attention but having little real effect:
examples: The call for a one-day national strike was dismissed as gesture politics.

meanings.definition: the ability of a computer to react to movements made by a human being and to do tasks according to what the movements mean:
examples: Advances in gesture recognition may mean that in future there will be no need for keyboards, mice, or joysticks.

meanings.definition: said to someone after they sneeze
used to wish good health to someone who has sneezed
to obtain, buy, or earn something:
examples: He went to the shop to get some milk.
I think she gets about £40,000 a year.
We stopped on the way to get some breakfast.
I managed to get all three suitcases for under $200.
How much did he get for his car? (= How much money did he sell it for?)
Where did you get your shoes from?

meanings.definition: to receive or be given something:
examples: I got quite a surprise when I saw her with short hair.
When did you get the news about Sam?
I got a phone call from Phil last night.
What grade did he get for the exam?
I got the impression that they'd rather be alone.
What did you get for your birthday?
We don't get much snow (= it does not often snow) here.
I managed to get a glimpse of him (= see him for a moment) through the crowds.
If you get a moment (= have time available), could you help me fill in that form?
She gets such pleasure from her garden.
If you can get some time off work, we could finish the decorating.
I can never get her to myself (= be alone with her) because she's always surrounded by people.

meanings.definition: to go somewhere and bring back someone or something:
examples: Let me go get my glasses.
Can I get you a drink?

meanings.definition: to take someone or something into your possession by force:
examples: Have the police got the man who did it yet?
Your cat got a bird this morning!

meanings.definition: to reach or arrive at a particular place:
examples: We hadn't even got as far as London when the car broke down.
What time does he normally get home (from work)?
If you get to the restaurant before us, just wait at the bar.

meanings.definition: to reach a particular stage, condition, or time:
examples: You earn loads of money if you get to the top in that profession.
It got to Thursday and she still hadn't heard any news.
I'm getting to the stage now where I just want to give up.

meanings.definition: to become ill with a disease, virus, etc.:
examples: I got food poisoning at that cheap little seafood restaurant.
Kids get all kinds of bugs at school.

meanings.definition: to become or start to be:
examples: He gets really upset if you mention his baldness.
Is your cold getting any better?
Your coffee's getting cold.
After a while you get used to all the noise.
You're getting to be such a big boy, aren't you!
How did you get to be a belly dancer?

meanings.definition: to cause something to happen, or cause someone or something to do something:
examples: She had to get the kids ready for school.
I'm trying to get this article finished by Thursday.
We get our groceries delivered.
Were you able to get the copy machine working?
I can't get my computer to work!

meanings.definition: to persuade someone to do something:
examples: Why don't you get Nicole to come to the party?

meanings.definition: to do something to something or someone without intending to or by accident:
examples: He got his bag caught in the train doors as they were closing.
I always get the two youngest sisters' names confused.

meanings.definition: sometimes used instead of "be" to form the passive:
examples: I got shouted at by some idiot for walking past his house.
They're getting married later this year.
This window got broken.

meanings.definition: to move to a different place or into a different position:
examples: I hit my head as I was getting into the car.
Get out of here now or I'll call the police.
The bed is too wide - we'll never get it through the door.
Getting up the ladder was easy enough - it was coming down that was the problem.
He got down on his knees and asked me to marry him!

meanings.definition: to travel somewhere in a train, bus, or other vehicle:
examples: Shall we get a taxi to the station?

meanings.definition: to deal with or answer a ringing phone, knock on the door, etc.:
examples: Hey, Ty, someone's at the door - would you get it, please?

meanings.definition: to have the chance to do something:
examples: I never get to see her now that she works somewhere else.

meanings.definition: to understand or hear something:
examples: I didn't get what he said because the music was so loud.
I told that joke to Sophia, but she didn't get it.

meanings.definition: to prepare a meal:
examples: I'll put the kids to bed while you're getting dinner ready.

meanings.definition: to pay for something:
examples: Put your money away - I'll get these drinks.

meanings.definition: to confuse someone and make them completely unable to understand or explain:
examples: Give him a technical question - that'll really get him!

meanings.definition: to annoy someone:
examples: It really gets to me the way we're expected to actually laugh at his pathetic jokes!

meanings.definition: to make someone feel strongly emotional and often cry:
examples: That part in the film when he finds out that his daughter is alive - that always gets me!

meanings.definition: to hit someone, especially with a bullet or something thrown:
examples: The bullet got her in the leg.

meanings.definition: to take something into your possession, or have something happen that you accept or receive:
examples: He climbed over the fence to get his ball back.
Monique raised her hand to get the teacher’s attention.
Can I get you a drink?
Dad keeps telling me to get a job.
What did you get on the test (= What mark did you receive)?
I think she gets (= earns) about $10 an hour.
We don’t get much snow in this part of the country (= It does not often snow).

meanings.definition: To get something often means to buy or pay for it:
examples: He went to the store to get milk.

meanings.definition: to become or start to be:
examples: Your coffee is getting cold.
He’s gotten so big, I hardly recognized him.
They’re getting married later this year.
Tom got lost in the woods.
What time do you get off work?
We’d better get going/moving or we’ll be late.

meanings.definition: to become ill with a disease:
examples: Everyone seems to be getting the flu.

meanings.definition: to cause something to be done or persuade someone to do something:
examples: The bed is too wide – we’ll never get it through the door.
I can’t get this printer to work!

meanings.definition: to prepare a meal:
examples: Why don’t you get supper ready?

meanings.definition: to move in a particular direction:
examples: Get away from that wet paint!
He got down on his hands and knees to look for his contact lens.
Her throat was so sore that she had trouble getting the medicine down (= swallowing it).
I hit my head as I was getting into the car.
Momma said we have to get these wet clothes off (= remove them).
Get your feet off the couch (= move them off it).

meanings.definition: To get off a road when you are driving means to turn onto another road:
examples: Get off the expressway at exit 43.

meanings.definition: To get off a train, bus, or aircraft is to leave it:
examples: Get off at Union Station.

meanings.definition: to go into a vehicle or aircraft for traveling:
examples: We could call for a taxi or get the bus.

meanings.definition: to arrive at a place or reach a stage in a process:
examples: We only got as far as Denver when the car broke down.
What time does he normally get home from work?
We’re not getting very far (= not advancing) with this computer program, are we?

meanings.definition: to understand:
examples: I think I got the general idea of the chapter.
The music was loud and I didn’t get what he said.
I never said he was mean – you’ve got it all wrong (= you are confused about this matter).

meanings.definition: to calculate the answer to a mathematical problem:
examples: What do you get if you divide 20 by 4?

meanings.definition: to answer a ringing telephone, a knock at the door, etc.:
examples: Hey, Juan, someone’s at the door – would you get it, please?

meanings.definition: to hit someone, esp. with something thrown or a bullet:
examples: My first throw missed, but the second got him in the leg.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to feel slightly angry:
examples: It gets me when I have to both cook dinner and clean the dishes.

meanings.definition: to have an emotional effect on someone:
examples: That scene in the movie, when the father and daughter are reunited, always gets me.

meanings.definition: to obtain, buy, or earn something:
examples: I think she gets about $40,000 a year.
How much did he get for his business when he sold it?

meanings.definition: to receive or be given something:
examples: The results we got from our market research team indicate that potential customers seem to like the new ad campaign.

meanings.definition: to reach a particular stage, condition, or time:
examples: Your earnings increase hugely if you get to the top in the legal profession.

meanings.definition: to pay for something:
examples: I'll get the bill.

meanings.definition: If a plan or activity gets off the ground or you get it off the ground, it starts or succeeds:
examples: A lot more money will be required to get this project off the ground.

meanings.definition: to start:
examples: He and his friend tried to start a band but it never got off the ground.

meanings.definition: to succeed in making someone understand or believe something:
examples: We can't get through to the government just how serious the problem is!
I don't seem to be able to get through to (= communicate with) him these days.

meanings.definition: to succeed in making someone understand something:
examples: What's got through to us is that email is totally impersonal - you need to talk to people.

get-a-bang-out-of.name: get a bang out of something

meanings.definition: to get pleasure from something; to find something interesting, exciting, or fun:
examples: Some of them got a bang out of throwing mud at each other.
The kids get a bang out of their video games.
Remember those old slapstick movies where everyone gets a bang out of seeing people fall over and get custard pies in the face?

get-a-buzz-out-of.name: get a buzz out of something/doing something

meanings.definition: to get a feeling of excitement, energy, and pleasure out of something:
examples: I get a buzz out of public speaking.
I got such a buzz out of seeing the kids' faces at the show.
You can see what a buzz she gets from helping others.
Some people get a buzz from the fact that they are recognized in the street.

meanings.definition: to have an opportunity to do something:
examples: I didn't get a chance to speak to her.
I would have liked to meet him, but I never got the chance.

meanings.definition: to end a marriage using an official or legal process:
examples: The last I heard they were getting a divorce.
He was lost for words when his wife told him that she wanted to get divorced.

meanings.definition: to begin to understand how to do something well:
examples: I practiced for a few hours before I really got a feel for the best way to do it.

meanings.definition: to make an effort to control your emotions and behave more calmly:
examples: I just think he ought to get a grip on himself - he's behaving like a child.

meanings.definition: to control your emotions:
examples: Get a grip on yourself, and tell me what happened.

meanings.definition: to start doing something before other people start, or before something happens, in order to win an advantage for yourself:
examples: I like to leave work early on Fridays so I can get a jump on the traffic.

meanings.definition: to get an advantage over other people by doing something before they do:
examples: The company is trying to get a jump on their competitors by putting a lot of money into research.

meanings.definition: something you say to a boring person when you want them to do more exciting things:
examples: Don't tell me you're cleaning the house on a Saturday night? Get a life, Hannah!

meanings.definition: infml stop being so boring or annoying and do something more interesting:
examples: Dave kept trying to tell me what to do, and I just told him to get a life.

meanings.definition: to find out information about someone that you do not know:
examples: I've been trying to get a line on the guy they've nominated with no luck.

get-a-load-of.name: get a load of him, her, you, etc.!

meanings.definition: said to make the person you are with look at or notice someone, and usually laugh at them:
examples: Get a load of him in his new clothes!

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to pay attention to a person or thing that is interesting, surprising, or attractive:
examples: Get a load of that, guys! Very nice.

meanings.definition: to hurry:
examples: Come on, you two, get a move on!
We need to get a move on if we're going to catch that train.

meanings.definition: infml hurry:
examples: Hey, Francine, get a move on or you’ll be late!

meanings.definition: to annoy someone:
examples: Steve always manages to get a rise out of me with his racist jokes.

meanings.definition: said to two people who are showing affection for each other in a very obvious way, especially when you think they should be doing this in private:
examples: When the couple carried on kissing, I just wanted to shout, "Get a room!"

meanings.definition: to hurry up:
examples: Get a wiggle on, or we'll miss the beginning of the concert.

meanings.definition: to have an opportunity to speak:
examples: Brad talked so much that nobody could get a word in edgewise.

meanings.definition: to hurry up:
examples: I haven't done my birth plan yet, so I'd better get a wriggle on.

get-a-foot-in-the-door.name: get a/your foot in the door

meanings.definition: to enter a business or organization at a low level, but with a chance of being more successful in the future:
examples: Making contacts can help you get a foot in the door when it comes to getting a job.

meanings.definition: to act as though you are more important than you really are:
examples: My father advised me to work hard, treat others with respect and never get above myself.
Anyone suspected of getting above himself would soon be cut down to size.
Ever since being given the power of attorney she’d been getting above herself.
One of my teachers said to me, “People like you don’t go to university. You’re getting above yourself.”
His colleagues fear that he has got above himself socially.

meanings.definition: to be successful in the work that you do:
examples: It's tough for a woman to get ahead in politics.

meanings.definition: to achieve success, often in your work or in society:
examples: You’ve got to take risks if you want to get ahead.

meanings.definition: to be successful in business or a job:
examples: If you are willing to work hard, you will get ahead in this organisation.

meanings.definition: to do something too early, or before you are ready or prepared:
examples: That last game suggests that we have been getting ahead of ourselves in praising the team's progress.
She didn't want to get ahead of herself and risk losing what she had achieved so far.

meanings.definition: to communicate with someone by phone:
examples: I’m trying to get ahold of some of these people for our meeting tomorrow.

meanings.definition: If two or more people get along, they like each other and are friendly to each other:
examples: I don't really get along with my sister's husband.

meanings.definition: to deal with a situation, usually successfully:
examples: I wonder how Michael is getting along in his new job?

meanings.definition: to have a good relationship or deal successfully with a situation:
examples: Alexis and her roommate are getting along better.
She doesn’t get on well with her father.

meanings.definition: to intentionally end a pregnancy:
examples: She decided to get an abortion.
She said that the proposed law would make it nearly impossible to get an abortion.

meanings.definition: to look at something or someone:
examples: Hey, get an eyeful of this!

meanings.definition: to travel to a lot of places:
examples: Spain last week and Germany this week - he gets around, doesn't he!

meanings.definition: to be able to go to different places without difficulty, especially if you are old or ill:
examples: My grandmother is finding it harder to get around these days.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         get round something UK
to find a way of dealing with or avoiding a problem:
examples: The committee is looking for ways to get around the funding problem.

meanings.definition: to travel or move from place to place:
examples: You need a car to get around town.
During her last few years, Edna couldn’t get around very well.
It didn’t take long for that rumor to get around the office.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         get round (somewhere) UK :
examples: News of Helen's pregnancy soon got around the office.

meanings.definition: to do something that you have intended to do for a long time:
examples: I still haven't got around to fixing that tap.

meanings.definition: to find time to do something that you have intended or would like to do:
examples: I wanted to see that movie but never got around to it.

meanings.definition: to criticize a person repeatedly:
examples: He keeps getting at me and I really don't know what I've done wrong.

meanings.definition: to influence a person illegally, usually by offering them money or threatening them:
examples: The accused claimed that the witness had been got at.

meanings.definition: to reach or obtain something, especially something that is difficult to get:
examples: I've put the cake on a high shelf where he can't get at it.

meanings.definition: When someone is getting at something, they mean it or are trying to express it:
examples: I'm not sure what you're getting at - don't you think I should come tonight?
What do you think the poet is getting at in these lines?

meanings.definition: to suggest or express something in a way that is not direct or clear:
examples: You mean I shouldn’t come tonight – is that what you’re getting at?

meanings.definition: to reach something:
examples: I keep cleaning supplies on a high shelf where my three-year-old can’t get at them.

meanings.definition: to leave or escape from a person or place, often when it is difficult to do this:
examples: We walked to the next beach to get away from the crowds.
I'll get away from work as soon as I can.

meanings.definition: to go somewhere to have a holiday, often because you need to rest:
examples: I just need to get away for a few days.

meanings.definition: to leave or escape:
examples: Wouldn’t it be nice to get away for a weekend?

meanings.definition: said when you do not believe or agree with what someone is saying:
examples: "Ralph painted that, you know." "Get away!"

meanings.definition: to go somewhere, usually on holiday, where you can completely relax and forget your responsibilities or problems:
examples: People go fishing to get away from it all.
We've decided to go hiking in the mountains to get away from it all.

meanings.definition: to be allowed to do things that other people would be punished or criticized for:
examples: He's so charming that he really does get away with murder.

meanings.definition: to succeed in avoiding punishment for something:
examples: If I thought I could get away with it, I wouldn't pay my taxes at all.

meanings.definition: to do something successfully although it is not the best way of doing it:
examples: Do you think we could get away with just one coat of paint on that wall?

meanings.definition: to escape blame or punishment when you do something wrong, or to avoid harm or criticism for something you did:
examples: She thought she could get away with cheating on her taxes.

meanings.definition: to succeed in avoiding punishment for something
to do something successfully although it is not the best way of doing it:
examples: In these fraud cases, prosecutors can't get away with going only for the mid-level guys, they have to go to the top.

meanings.definition: to return to a place after you have been somewhere else:
examples: If you get back in time, you can come with us.
When we got back to the hotel, Ann had already left.

meanings.definition: to do something unpleasant to someone because they have done something unpleasant to you:
examples: I'll get you back for this, just you wait!
I think he's trying to get back at her for those remarks she made in the meeting.

meanings.definition: to be given something again that you had before:
examples: He went next door to get his ball back.
Don't lend him money - you'll never get it back.

meanings.definition: to return, esp. to your home:
examples: When did you get back from Hawaii?

meanings.definition: to obtain something again after loss or separation:
examples: She was thrilled to get her old job back.

meanings.definition: to be given something again that you had before:
examples: If you're not careful when you invest in some markets, you'll never get your money back.

meanings.definition: to punish someone because that person has done something wrong to you:
examples: I think he’s trying to get back at her for what she said in the meeting.

meanings.definition: to talk to someone again, usually on the phone, in order to give them some information or because you were not able to speak to them before:
examples: I'll get back to you later with those figures.

meanings.definition: to start doing or talking about something again:
examples: Anyway, I'd better get back to work.

meanings.definition: to continue doing something that you were doing or that you started earlier:
examples: If you skip some days, it can be hard to get back to a regular bicycling routine.

meanings.definition: to communicate with someone at a later time:
examples: He can’t find the phone number right now, but promised to get back to me with it.

meanings.definition: to talk to someone again in order to give them some information or because you were not able to speak to them before:
examples: Finance promised to get back to me later with those figures.

meanings.definition: to fail to do as much work or pay as much money as you should by a particular time:
examples: She got behind with her mortgage and the house was repossessed.

meanings.definition: to fail to do as much work or pay as much money as you should by a particular time:
examples: The agency had gotten behind with its work and needed outside help.
The two got behind on bills and negotiations with lenders led nowhere.

meanings.definition: to support somebody or something:
examples: If every member of the top management team doesn't get behind this project, it's never going to work.

meanings.definition: to become very angry or upset:
examples: I'm not getting bent out of shape because people don't respect my opinion. I'm used to that.

meanings.definition: to improve:
examples: After the ceasefire, the situation in the capital got better.
She's getting much better at pronouncing English words.
The technology is getting better all the time.
The situation will probably get worse before it gets better.
As time went on, things gradually got better.
As a team, we very much want to get better.

meanings.definition: to manage to stop something from affecting you, upsetting you, or influencing you:
examples: Somehow we need to get beyond our angry feelings and talk about a solution.
If you can get beyond all the jargon, the site is full of useful tips.

meanings.definition: to progress to a better or more developed stage than something:
examples: His performance rarely gets beyond caricature.
Educators must ensure that every student gets beyond the basic literacy skills of the early-elementary grades.

get-blood-out-of-from-a-stone.name: get blood out of/from a stone

meanings.definition: to make someone give or tell you something, when it is extremely difficult because of the character or mood of the person or organization you are dealing with:
examples: Persuading Chris to buy a round of drinks is like getting blood from a stone.

meanings.definition: to be able to live or deal with a situation with difficulty, usually by having just enough of something you need, such as money:
examples: How can he get by on so little money?
We can get by with four computers at the moment, but we'll need a couple more when the new staff arrive.

meanings.definition: to manage or continue to exist in a state or situation where something is lacking:
examples: When we were students we got by on very little money.
There is tremendous pressure on families trying to get by without health insurance.

meanings.definition: to be able to live or deal with a situation by having very little of something you need, such as money:
examples: It was many years before she was in a financial position to do anything beyond getting by.

meanings.definition: to become involved in something, often without wanting to:
examples: They were having an argument and somehow I got caught up in it.
The danger is that innocent people will get caught up in it.
It's easy to get caught up in the whirlwind of activity.
I think we all got caught up in the excitement of the moment.
I don't know quite what happened but he got caught up in a brawl outside the bar.
I try not to get caught up in the madness.

get-caught-with-hand-in-the-cookie-jar.name: get caught with your hand in the cookie jar

meanings.definition: used to say that someone has been stealing or doing something wrong:
examples: He only returned the money when he got caught with his hand in the cookie jar.

meanings.definition: to suddenly become too frightened to do something you had planned to do, especially something important such as getting married
to feel too frightened to do something that you had planned to do:
examples: I was going to try bungee jumping, but I got cold feet.

meanings.definition: to start doing something quickly:
examples: Get cracking (= hurry), or we'll miss the train.
I'd better get cracking on the food for tonight.

meanings.definition: to be given praise, approval, or honour for something you have done:
examples: I'm not getting credit for what I'm doing.

He never gets enough credit for writing such beautiful tunes.

meanings.definition: to be given the legal right or duty to care for someone, especially a child, after its parents have separated or died:
examples: My parents divorced and my father got custody.
She said she wanted her mother to get custody of her children in the event of her death.
He lived with his parents while he fought to gain custody of his two children.
To gain temporary legal custody, a grandparent will need to file a petition with the court.

meanings.definition: to become or start to be dark because the sun has gone down:
examples: It's only four o'clock and it's already getting dark.
It was starting to get dark so I turned the lights on.

meanings.definition: to start talking about the most important or basic facts of a situation:
examples: Let's get down to brass tacks. Who's paying for all this?

meanings.definition: to start talking about the subject to be discussed:
examples: If the introductions are over I'd like to get down to business.

meanings.definition: to start to direct your efforts and attention towards something:
examples: I've got a lot of work to do, but I can't seem to get down to it.
I must get down to booking the hotels.

meanings.definition: to start to direct your efforts and attention to something, esp. work:
examples: We’ve got to get down to business, folks, or we’ll never get the newsletter out on time.

meanings.definition: to start to direct your efforts and attention towards something:
examples: The meeting's not due to start for another five minutes but we're all here, so let's get down to business.

meanings.definition: to punish someone who has done something bad to you by doing something equally bad to that person:
examples: After she insulted me, all I thought about was how I could get even with her.

meanings.definition: to do something equally bad to someone who has done something bad to you
to make progress or to improve:
examples: She's taking flute lessons, but she really doesn't seem to be getting anywhere with it.
It's been hard settling in, but I feel like I'm getting somewhere at last.
We didn't get very far with that plan, did we?
The chances are you're not going to get very far if you don't ask for help.
At last, I think we're getting somewhere.
It's been a long slog but I feel we're finally getting somewhere.

meanings.definition: to start to go or move:
examples: We'd better get moving or we'll be late.
I've just seen the time - I'd better get going.
Come on, we need to get moving.
It's been a wonderful visit, but I really need to get going or I'll miss my train.

meanings.definition: to find someone or obtain something: to understand something:
examples: Where can I get hold of some stamps?

This is a very difficult concept to get hold of.

meanings.definition: to communicate with someone, esp. by telephone:
examples: I haven’t talked to her in years, so I wouldn’t know how to get hold of her anymore.

meanings.definition: to obtain something:
examples: Where can I get hold of today’s newspaper?

meanings.definition: to succeed in entering a place, especially by using force or a trick:
examples: They must have got in through the bathroom window.

meanings.definition: to arrive at your home or the place where you work:
examples: What time did you get in last night?

meanings.definition: If a train or other vehicle gets in at a particular time, that is when it arrives:

meanings.definition: to send something so that it arrives by a particular time:

meanings.definition: to succeed in saying something, although it is difficult to do this because other people are talking too:

meanings.definition: to manage to find time to do something or deal with someone:
examples: I want to get a little bit more work in before I leave the office.

meanings.definition: to buy a supply of something, usually food or drink, so that you will have enough of what you need:
examples: We'll have to get some food in for the weekend if we're having visitors.

meanings.definition: to ask a trained person to come to your home to do some paid work:
examples: We'll have to get a plumber in to look at that water tank.

meanings.definition: to arrive at a place:
examples: What time did you say his plane gets in?

meanings.definition: to be elected to a political position:
examples: If Archer gets in as mayor, he’s likely to raise taxes.

meanings.definition: to manage to find time for doing something:
examples: I’d like to get in some skiing while we’re in Colorado.

meanings.definition: to succeed in saying something, often in a situation where other people talk a lot:
examples: She tried to get her suggestion in at the start of the meeting.

meanings.definition: to worry:
examples: He tends to get in a sweat about flying.

meanings.definition: to start to take part in an activity that is already happening because you will win an advantage from it:
examples: A Japanese company tried to get in on the deal.

meanings.definition: to be involved in or benefit from something when there is an opportunity:
examples: If you'd like to get in on this offer, call now.

meanings.definition: to start to take part in an activity that is already happening because you will win an advantage from it:
examples: A Japanese company tried to get in on the deal.

meanings.definition: to take advantage of something that someone else started:
examples: We designed the Web page, and now everyone else in our class wants to get in on the act.

meanings.definition: to annoy someone, usually by being present all the time:
examples: My flatmate has been getting in my hair a lot recently.

meanings.definition: to annoy you, usually by being present all the time:
examples: The children have been getting in my hair all afternoon.

meanings.definition: something you say when something good happens to someone
to succeed in being chosen or elected:
examples: He wanted to go to Cambridge, but he didn't get in.
Will the politician keep his promises when he gets into office?

meanings.definition: If you do not know what has got into someone, you do not understand why they are behaving strangely:
examples: I can't think what's got into him. He doesn't usually get so angry.

meanings.definition: to become interested in an activity or subject, or start being involved in an activity:
examples: She's been getting into yoga recently - she does three classes a week.

meanings.definition: to (cause someone to) become involved in a difficult situation, often without intending to:

meanings.definition: to become interested in something:
examples: The bosses of the dairy company are now getting into yogurt and ice cream in a big way.

meanings.definition: to start to understand, enjoy, and be active in something:

meanings.definition: to become familiar with and confident at something you have recently started doing:
examples: Let's wait until she's got into her stride before we ask her to negotiate that contract.

meanings.definition: to be punished for something you did:
examples: When Mom finds out you skipped school yesterday, you’re going to get it.

meanings.definition: to be punished or severely criticized for something that you have done:
examples: Poor old Bob got it in the neck for being late.

get-it-into-your-thick-head.name: get it into your thick head

meanings.definition: to make someone understand something, especially when you have told them many times before and are annoyed:
examples: How can I get it into your thick head that it’s dangerous to swim that far out in the sea?

meanings.definition: to have sex:
examples: Did you get it on with him?

get-it-through-thick-head.name: get it through your thick head

meanings.definition: infml to cause someone to understand something:
examples: How can I get it through your thick head that it’s dangerous to swim that far out in the ocean?

get-it-through-your-thick-head.name: get it through your thick head

meanings.definition: to make someone understand something, especially when you have told them many times before and are annoyed:
examples: How can I get it through your thick head that it’s dangerous to swim that far out in the ocean?

meanings.definition: to get something organized:
examples: We were going to go skiing over Christmas but we never got it together.

meanings.definition: to start to want to travel or do something different:
examples: After three years in the job she began to get itchy feet.

meanings.definition: a rude way of telling someone who is annoying you to go away

meanings.definition: used to tell someone forcefully and quite rudely to go away:

meanings.definition: infml go away:

meanings.definition: to meet someone you can have a sexual or romantic relationship with:

meanings.definition: to completely fail to achieve something:

meanings.definition: to leave a place, usually in order to start a journey:

meanings.definition: to leave work with permission, usually at the end of the day:

meanings.definition: to have or give someone an orgasm:

meanings.definition: to avoid punishment, or to help another person to avoid punishment for something:

examples: He got off with a suspended sentence of three years for practicing medicine without a license.

get-off-or-get-off.name: get off (sth) or get sb off (sth)

meanings.definition: to avoid punishment, or to help another person to avoid punishment for something:

meanings.definition: to experience less serious punishment, injury, or harm than you might have expected:

meanings.definition: to find something exciting, especially in a sexual way:

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning to force yourself to start doing something or to make yourself hurry:

meanings.definition: to give something to each of a number of people:

meanings.definition: to stop doing something, usually something annoying:

meanings.definition: to cause something:

meanings.definition: fml to cause something to exist:

meanings.definition: to phone someone:

to give someone help:

Marcia has taught her children to lend a hand when it comes to cleaning up after meals.

meanings.definition: to make things difficult or unpleasant for someone:
examples: Her kids always give her a hard time when she takes them shopping.
My mother gave me a really hard time (= was angry with me) about staying out late.

meanings.definition: to tell someone that something is going to happen:
examples: I just wanted to give you all a heads up that we will be talking about the first two chapters of the book tomorrow.

meanings.definition: to tell someone that something is going to happen:
examples: I just wanted to give you all a heads up that we will be talking about the first two chapters of the book tomorrow.

meanings.definition: to help someone to climb over somethingto help someone to improve their situation, especially at work
to make someone happier:
examples: She'd been feeling low but hearing that she'd got the job gave her a lift.
It gives you a bit of a lift to know you're doing something to help other people.
I try to give them a lift by finding something about their work to praise.
He'd been feeling pessimistic about his court case, but that evening, he received some information that gave him a lift.
The win last week really gave her a lift.

meanings.definition: to shout something angry at someone, usually using offensive language:
examples: A taxi driver wound down his window and gave the cyclist a mouthful.

give-a-piece-of-mind.name: give someone a piece of your mind

meanings.definition: to tell someone why you are angry with that person:
examples: I’d like to give her a piece of my mind.

give-a-piece-of-your-mind.name: give someone a piece of your mind

meanings.definition: to speak angrily to someone about something they have done wrong:
examples: I'm going to give that mechanic a piece of my mind if the car's not fixed this time.

meanings.definition: to tell someone something:
examples: Give me a shout when you've finished in the bathroom.

meanings.definition: to tell someone what they should do or how they should behave in a particular situation:
examples: We're here to help young people and to give them advice.
The doctor gave us advice on the symptoms we should look out for.
Steven gave me some good advice.

give-someone-an-inch-and-they-ll-take-a-.name: give someone an inch and they'll take a mile

meanings.definition: said about someone who has been given a small amount of power or freedom to do something, and then has tried to get a lot more
to give someone complete freedom to do something:
examples: The landlord has given her carte blanche to redecorate the living room.
Congress has effectively given the president carte blanche.
If I was given carte blanche, I would teach a very different curriculum.

give-credit-for.name: give someone credit for something/doing something

meanings.definition: to say that someone deserves praise, approval, or honour for something they have done:
examples: He gave the board credit for supporting him as he made major changes.
You have to give credit to the other team for never giving up.
If a member of my team comes up with a great idea, I'm happy to give them the credit.

meanings.definition: to think that someone has a good quality, when you later realize that they do not:
examples: I gave him credit for better judgment than he showed.
I gave you credit for being kinder than that.

meanings.definition: to look at someone in a way that shows you are angry or dislike them:
examples: Complete strangers gave her evils in the street.
He was giving me evils and some of those tackles he made were really tough.

meanings.definition: to hit someone's open hand with your own to celebrate doing something well or achieving something, especially in sports
to make someone think seriously about something
If someone gives you hell, they criticize you severely: If something gives you hell, it causes you a lot of pain:
examples: She gave me hell for being 20 minutes late.
These new shoes are giving me hell.

meanings.definition: slang to criticize someone angrily:
examples: The boss gave me hell for not telling him about it.

meanings.definition: to ask someone who works for you to leave their job, usually after a particular period of time:
examples: My boss gave me a month's notice.
They gave me my notice yesterday.
The law here requires employers to give workers notice of two months minimum.
He just gave me two weeks' notice.
How much notice did they give him before they laid him off?

meanings.definition: to tell your employer or landlord that you will be leaving your job or your rented home, usually after a particular period of time:
examples: I gave my notice at work yesterday.
She gave her landlord two months' notice that she was not going to renew her lease.
Your contract requires you to give us at least two weeks' notice before ending your employment with us, or else you forfeit the right to be paid back for your accumulated time off.
How much notice did you give your job?

meanings.definition: to cause someone to stop and think about what they were doing or intending to do

give-something-to-talk-about.name: give someone something to talk about

meanings.definition: to provide someone with an interesting subject to discuss:
examples: Our new car will give the neighbours something to talk about.

give-the-benefit-of-the-doubt.name: give someone the benefit of the doubt

meanings.definition: to believe something good about someone, rather than something bad, when you have the possibility of doing either:
examples: I didn't know whether his story was true or not, but I decided to give him the benefit of the doubt.

meanings.definition: to decide that you will believe someone, even though you are not sure that what the person is saying is true:
examples: She said she was late because her flight was canceled, and we gave her the benefit of the doubt.

meanings.definition: to show someone that you are sexually interested in them:
examples: That girl's definitely giving me the come-on.
When Sandy offered to buy me a drink, I guessed that I was being given the come-on.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to have uncomfortable feelings of nervousness or fear:
examples: Living next to a graveyard would give me the creeps.

He was a mild-mannered novelist who liked nothing better than to give his readers the creeps.
That empty house is totally giving me the creeps - let's get out of here!
The strange music was really giving him the creeps.

meanings.definition: to end your romantic relationship with someone
to show someone in an offensive way that you are angry with that person by turning the back of your hand towards them and putting your middle finger up
to honour someone by giving them special rights in a particular city:
examples: The pensioner will be given the freedom of Chester today at the age of 93.
In 1910, Hardy was given the freedom of the borough.
The cricketer was later given the freedom of Cheltenham.
The former President was even given the freedom of the city.
All three men are to be given the freedom of Belfast.

meanings.definition: to look at someone in a way that shows you find them sexually attractive:
examples: All the men were giving her the glad eye.

meanings.definition: to take someone's job away from them, usually because that person has done something wrong: to end a romantic relationship with someone
examples: The newspaper's foreign editor was given the heave-ho yesterday.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel nervous or frightened:
examples: Stop it. You're giving me the jimjams.
This whole deal's giving me the jim-jams.

meanings.definition: to make someone nervous or frightened:
examples: Come away from that cliff edge! You're giving me the jitters!

meanings.definition: to tell someone to leave their job: to end a relationship with someone:
examples: I heard he'd been given the push.
Oh, give him the push - he's a loser.

meanings.definition: to annoy someone
to escape from someone who is following or chasing you:
examples: The robber took to the rooftops, and that's how he gave the police the slip.
He raced around the corner and managed to give his bully the slip.
Despite years of bad stock trades and malfeasance, he hired a good lawyer and gave the Securities and Exchange Commission the slip.
The forward gave the defender the slip and kick home a goal late in the quarter.
As an actress who values her privacy, she's gotten very good at giving the paparazzi the slip.

give-the-time-of-day.name: give someone the time of day

meanings.definition: If someone will not give you the time of day, they are unfriendly and refuse to speak to you:
examples: We had an argument with our neighbours, and now they won't even give us the time of day.

meanings.definition: said when you are praising someone for something good they have done, although you dislike other things about them:
examples: He failed again, but to give him his due, he did try hard.
To give her her due, she was the opposite of workshy.
He wasn't a natural leader, it's true, but to give him his due, it wasn't for lack of effort.
You have to give him his due: he did his best and that's all you can ask for, really.
I know the company failed, but to give them their due, they really made a go of it.

meanings.definition: to tell someone something or cause someone to think that something is true:
examples: I was given to understand she was staying at this hotel.
We were given to understand that the money would be distributed evenly between the surviving children.
Her comments that evening gave me to understand that they lived separate lives, but perhaps I was mistaken.

At the hospital, I was given to understand that home care would be provided for two weeks after my discharge.

meanings.definition: to think that someone is certain to die or to be dead:
examples: The doctors had virtually given her up for dead, but she eventually recovered.
After a three-day search on the mountain, they gave him up for dead.
He'd been missing so long, even his wife had given him up for dead.
I wasn't going to give up on her if there was the smallest possibility she was alive.
Her mother refused to give her up for dead.

meanings.definition: to speak angrily to someone whose behaviour you strongly disapprove of

give-a-run-for-money.name: give someone/something a run for their money

meanings.definition: to not allow someone to win easily: to be similar in quality to or almost better than someone or something:
examples: We're going to give the other candidate a run for her money.
He's so good at maths that he gives his teacher a run for her money.
This small, independent cosmetics manufacturer gives the big brands a run for their money.

meanings.definition: to be as good at something as someone who is extremely good:
examples: He’ll give those professional players a run for their money.

meanings.definition: to tickle a person or an animal:
examples: The dog was lying on his back, waiting for me to give him a tickle.
Do you want me to give you a tickle?
The baby loves it when I give her a tickle.
The cat rolled over so we could give him a tickle.
Come here and I'll give you a tickle!
He loves it if you give him a tickle behind his ears.

meanings.definition: If you give someone or something the cold shoulder, you intentionally ignore them or show no interest in them:
examples: She was so upset that she gave him the cold shoulder for the whole weekend.

meanings.definition: to attempt something:
examples: Only a few people are successful as professional athletes, but it's worth giving it a go.
If I got the opportunity I'd certainly give it a go.
We've got nothing to lose so let's give it a go.

meanings.definition: to avoid or not do something:
examples: We usually go to France in the summer, but we've decided to give it a miss this year.

"Are you coming to the cinema this afternoon?" "I've got too much work - I think I'm going to have to give it a miss."

meanings.definition: to attempt to do something, often for the first time:
examples: I've never danced salsa before but I'll give it a whirl.

meanings.definition: to try something for the first time:
examples: I’ve never done cross-country skiing before, but I thought I’d give it a whirl this winter.

meanings.definition: to give something to someone without asking for payment:
examples: The shop is giving away a sample to every customer.

meanings.definition: to tell people something secret, often without intending to:
examples: The party was meant to be a surprise, but Sharon gave it away.

meanings.definition: to allow an opponent to score a goal or win a game by making a mistake or doing something very badly :
examples: You can't give away goals as easily as we did and win games at this level.

meanings.definition: to show someone's secret feelings:
examples: She thinks no one knows how much she likes him, but her face when I said he'd be there really gave her away!

meanings.definition: in a marriage ceremony, to formally bring a woman who is getting married to the front of the church so that she is standing at the side of her future partner, and then to give permission for her to marry:
examples: The bride was given away by her father.

meanings.definition: to tell a secret or show your feelings unintentionally:
examples: I'm not giving away any plot surprises; read the review in the paper if you want to know them.
The look on her face gave her away (= showed her real feelings).

meanings.definition: to supply something at no charge:
examples: They’re giving away shopping bags.

meanings.definition: to provide or offer something to someone for free:
examples: We're giving away thousands of free DVDs if you spend over $50!

meanings.definition: to return something to the person who gave it to you:
examples: Has she given you those books back yet?

meanings.definition: to produce heat, light, a smell, or a gas:
examples: That tiny radiator doesn't give off much heat.

meanings.definition: to produce something as a result of a natural process:
examples: The forest fire gave off thick black smoke.

meanings.definition: to give another person the use of something, or the responsibility for something or someone:
examples: We've given the attic over to the children.

give-up-as-a-bad-job.name: give something up as a bad job

meanings.definition: to stop doing something because you do not feel it is worth continuing:
examples: After three attempts to mend it, I gave it up as a bad job.

meanings.definition: to do something as well as you can
to avoid a person or place:
examples: I tend to give the city centre a wide berth on Saturdays because it's so busy.

meanings.definition: to allow something or someone to remain in your house:
examples: Most of the furniture is so ugly, you wouldn't give it houseroom.

meanings.definition: to look at and examine something or someone quickly:
examples: The security guards gave me the once-over, but they didn't ask me for any identification.

give-the-green-light-to.name: give the green light to something

meanings.definition: to prove that something is not true:

meanings.definition: to stop trying to guess:

meanings.definition: to stop owning, using, or claiming something:

meanings.definition: to stop doing something before you have finished it, usually because it is too difficult:
examples: I've given up trying to help her.

meanings.definition: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it:

meanings.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:

meanings.definition: to stop having a friendship with someone:

meanings.definition: to allow the police or an enemy to take you as a prisoner:

meanings.definition: to stop doing or to stop having something:
examples: He gave up jogging after his heart attack.

meanings.definition: To give up also means to lose or be defeated:
examples: Although behind in the chess match, he refused to give up.

meanings.definition: to stop trying to do something before you have finished, usually because it is too difficult:
examples: She has a struggle trying to persuade the board to accept her proposal, but she's determined not to give up.

meanings.definition: to stop hoping that a particular thing will happen:

meanings.definition: to expect someone or something to fail:
examples: Most people gave up on him when he dropped out, but he went back and earned his degree two years later.

meanings.definition: to expect someone or something to fail:
examples: Most people gave up on him when he quit school, but he went back and earned his degree two years later.

meanings.definition: to dieIf a machine gives up the ghost, it stops working: to stop trying to do something because you know that you will not succeed:
examples: Our old TV had finally given up the ghost.

meanings.definition: to express your ideas or feelings in spoken words:
examples: She has one great fear to which she will never give utterance.

meanings.definition: to express your thoughts or feelings in words:
examples: I always had doubts about the project but I never gave voice to them.

meanings.definition: to allow other vehicles to go past before you move onto a road: to break, especially when under pressure from strong forces: to stop arguing or fighting against someone or something:
examples: You have to give way to traffic coming from the right.

meanings.definition: to break or fall down suddenly:

meanings.definition: to be replaced by something, especially because it is better, cheaper, easier, etc.:

meanings.definition: to be replaced by something:
examples: My excitement gave way to fear when I drove a car for the first time.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that they are being silly or unreasonable and should change the way they think about things:
examples: Give your head a shake, people, and figure it out: more cars on the road is not the solution.

meanings.definition: to continue to have a close involvement in a particular thing for the whole of your life:

meanings.definition: to promise:
examples: He gave his word that he would marry her and she had no cause to doubt him.

meanings.definition: to spend all your time and energy doing or feeling something:

meanings.definition: in sports such as football and hockey, an occasion when a player passes the ball and then moves quickly into a position where they can receive the ball:

give-and-go passes

meanings.definition: to develop and use emotions or ideas completely:

meanings.definition: to allow a trained person to take some blood from your body so that it can be stored and is ready to be given to people who have lost a lot of blood in an accident or operation:

meanings.definition: to help someone:

meanings.definition: something that is given free to a customer
something that tells or shows something secret, often without intending to:
examples: He said he'd given up smoking, but the empty packs in the bin were a dead giveaway (= clearly showed the secret truth).

meanings.definition: a situation in a game such as football or ice hockey when a player's actions cause the ball, puck, or a point to be lost to another player or the other team:
examples: a giveaway goal

meanings.definition: A giveaway price is very low:
examples: The furniture shop's offering three-piece suites at giveaway prices.

meanings.definition: something that communicates information, esp. when there is no intention to do this:
examples: The look on his face when her name is mentioned is a dead giveaway.

meanings.definition: something provided at no charge, or for which nothing is expected in return:
examples: The tax cuts represent a giveaway by the government to these businesses.

meanings.definition: something that is given free to a customer:
examples: You might want to consider other forms of giveaway if your products are unsuitable to offer as samples or gifts.

meanings.definition: used to describe a price that is very low:
examples: The furniture shop's offering three-piece suites at give-away prices

meanings.definition: a reduction in employees’ pay when a business is having problems, usually made on the agreement that pay will be increased again when business improves:
examples: The giveback was voluntary and each individual was free to make the decision based on his or her own personal situation.

meanings.definition:
past participle of
        
         give
knowing about or considering a particular thing:
examples: Given his age, he's a remarkably fast runner.
Given (the fact) that he's had six months to do this, he hasn't made much progress.

meanings.definition: already decided, arranged, or agreed:
examples: At the given signal, the group rushed forward to the barrier.
The bomb could go off at any given (= any) time and in any given (= any) place.

meanings.definition: something that is certain to happen:
examples: You can take it as a given that there will be champagne at the wedding.

meanings.definition: past participle of give
something that is certain to happen or to be:
examples: It’s a given that if he is defeated for reelection, he’ll be offered a position in the administration.

meanings.definition: considering:
examples: Given his age, he’s in excellent physical condition.

meanings.definition: already decided, arranged, or agreed:
examples: At any given time (= at any particular time), the jury may reach a verdict, so we’d better stay nearby.

meanings.definition: something that is certain to happen:
examples: It's a given that the role of government in American life is going to expand over the next few years.

meanings.definition: If someone would do something given half a chance, they would certainly do it if the opportunity came up:
examples: I'd give up work given half a chance.

meanings.definition: the name that is chosen for you at birth and is not your family name:
examples: Her family name is Smith and her given names are Mary Elizabeth.

meanings.definition: your first name
if I were allowed to, or if I could choose:
examples: Given the chance, I'd spend all day reading.

meanings.definition: a person who gives something to someone:
examples: I thanked the giver of every gift in person.

I'm a regular advice giver on this blog.

meanings.definition: a person or company that gives money or goods to an organization:
examples: Having a star attached to your charity does attract more givers.

corporate givers

meanings.definition: the act of providing money for something, especially to a charity or other good cause:
examples: Corporate giving has declined markedly since the beginning of the recession.

meanings.definition: any small device with a particular purpose:
examples: electronic gizmos

meanings.definition: any small device:
examples: The store is full of gizmos like pagers and cellular telephones.

meanings.definition: a small object or machine that is designed for a particular purpose:
examples: Oh, the gadgets and gizmos you can buy - for only $100.
high-tech/electronic gizmo

meanings.definition: a part of bird's stomach that has thick muscles, where food is ground down (= broken into small pieces by pressing or squeezing), especially with very small stones:
examples: Most water birds keep grit, quartz, and other small stones in their muscular gizzard to help grind up food.

meanings.definition: the smooth part in the centre of the forehead that is above and between the eyebrows:
examples: Most nosebleeds are controlled with direct pressure to the glabella and nasal alae.

meanings.definition: (of fruit) preserved in liquid sugar:
examples: Decorate the cake with glacé fruits and nuts of your choice.
glacé ginger/pear/pineapple
pear glacé

meanings.definition: a cherry (= a small, round, soft red or black fruit with a single hard seed in the middle), usually red in colour, that has had its seed removed and been preserved in liquid sugar:
examples: You can decorate the cake with glacé cherries.
