meanings.definition: made or left by a glacier:
examples: glacial deposits

meanings.definition: extremely cold:
examples: glacial temperatures
a glacial period

meanings.definition: extremely unfriendly:
examples: She gave me a glacial stare.

meanings.definition: extremely slow:
examples: The case is moving forward at a glacial pace.

meanings.definition:
short for
        
         glacial period  : a very cold period during the earth's history when large masses of ice covered much of the earth's surface:
examples: An ice core dating back 740,000 years has revealed eight ice ages, or glacials, followed by shorter interglacial periods.

meanings.definition: a time in the past when the temperature was very cold and glaciers covered large parts of the earth
in a way that involves a glacier (= a large mass of ice that moves slowly):
examples: The shifting ice produced the glacially dammed lakes to the southwest.

meanings.definition: If a place is glacially cold, it is extremely cold:
examples: The house was large, built of stone, and glacially cold throughout the year.
On that glacially cold morning I stood shivering in the crowd.

meanings.definition: used meaning "extremely" with other words that might also describe glaciers or ice:
examples: His work embodies a glacially cool perfection.
He looks at me through glacially blue eyes.

meanings.definition: extremely slowly:
examples: Where the clean-up has occurred, it has moved glacially.

meanings.definition: in a way that is extremely unfriendly or emotionally cold:
examples: The audience was greeted by a glacially smiling Lady Macbeth.

meanings.definition: formed or covered by glaciers:
examples: the glaciated peaks of the Himalayas

meanings.definition: the forming, existence, or movement of glaciers over the surface of the earth:

meanings.definition: to disappear:
examples: It was weeks before the bruises went away.

meanings.definition: If something has gone AWOL, it is not in its usual place or has been stolen:
examples: Two computers have gone AWOL from the office.

meanings.definition: to return:
examples: That restaurant was terrible - I'm never going back there again.
I'll have to go back for my umbrella.
Do you think you'll ever go back to London?
When do you go back to school?
Let's go back to the beginning and start again.
We can always go back to the original plan if necessary.

meanings.definition: to be returned:
examples: When are these library books supposed to go back ?
That TV will have to go back to the shop - it hasn't worked properly ever since I bought it.

meanings.definition: to have existed since a time in the past:
examples: Their relationship goes back to when they were at college together.
Our house goes back to (= has existed since) the 18th century.

meanings.definition: If people go back a long way, they have known each other for a long time.
to fail to keep a promise, or to change a decision or agreement:
examples: The government looks likely to go back on its decision to close the mines.
She's gone back on her word and decided not to give me the job after all.

meanings.definition: to fail to keep a promise, or to change a decision or agreement:
examples: Jason is totally unreliable and always goes back on his word.

meanings.definition: to not keep a promise, or to change a decision or agreement:
examples: The government looks likely to go back on its decision to close the mines.

meanings.definition: used to show that you are annoyed with someone for not paying attention:
examples: "Sorry, what did you say?" "Oh, go back to sleep!"

meanings.definition: to start a relationship again with a person you had a romantic relationship with in the past:
examples: I hear he's ended the affair and gone back to his wife.

meanings.definition: to start doing something again that you were doing before:
examples: It's time to go back to work.

go-back-to-the-drawing-board.name: go back to the drawing board

meanings.definition: to start planning something again because the first plan failed
a bag or container holding necessary supplies such as food to last for a few days, for use in an emergency:
examples: I got a a new knife and flashlight for my go bag.

meanings.definition: to become extremely angry:
examples: If your dad finds out you've been skipping school, he'll go ballistic.
When The New York Times wrote an article that was critical of the president, the White House went ballistic.
People went ballistic when they were asked to give up their parking spaces.
He goes ballistic if you even mention his ex-wife's name.
Passengers were going ballistic about the delays.

meanings.definition: to become extremely angry or excited:
examples: She'll go bananas when you tell her the news.
When she came onto the stage, the crowd went bananas.
I just went bananas when I found out what he had done.
When we arrived, Mary was going bananas and shouting at everyone.
Sales people go bananas when they see what you can do with this software.

meanings.definition: to make a sudden loud noise:
examples: The balloon went bang when it landed on the bush.
I was just starting to pull away from the light when the engine went bang.
David brought some of those party poppers that go bang and spray paper streamers everywhere.
When fireworks explode, the air around them expands rapidly, and that's why they go bang.
When the prop gun goes bang, that's your cue to fall to the floor.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         bare
to have a red face because you are embarrassed:
examples: Whenever I talked about his past life, he would go beet red.

meanings.definition: If something is going begging, it is available to be taken because no one else wants it:
examples: If that bottle of wine is going begging, I'll have it.

meanings.definition: If a company or plan goes belly up, it fails:
examples: The business went belly up after only six months.

meanings.definition: to be more than or not limited to something:
examples: The appeal of this device goes beyond convenience.
The behaviour of people with ADHD goes beyond occasional fidgeting or disorganization.
His sense of adventure went beyond a mere love of travel.
As a doctor, her focus goes beyond medicine to include all aspects of primary care.

meanings.definition: to pick wild blackberries:
examples: Sometimes George would ask me to go blackberrying with him.
I'm going blackberrying. Anyone want to join me?
We go blackberrying here because it's away from the road and there's less chance of pollution.
I always used to go blackberrying there when I was a kid.
I went blackberrying with Helen and Tom at the weekend.

meanings.definition: to forget something that you know, often temporarily:
examples: I went blank and couldn't think of a single example.
When she asked me his name, my mind went blank.

meanings.definition: to lose all your money or become bankrupt (= unable to pay what you owe and losing legal control of your finances):
examples: Many small businesses went broke during the recession.
Our farmers are going broke because of cheap imports.

meanings.definition: If a company goes bust, it is forced to close because it is financially unsuccessful:
examples: More than 20 companies in the district went bust during the last three months.
People who've booked flights are naturally worried about what will happen if the airline goes bust.
The fund was set up to help people who lost their pensions when their employers went bust.
So what happens if your electricity supplier goes bust?
Several local companies have gone bust as a result of rising costs.

meanings.definition: to move past, in space or time:
examples: You can watch the trains going by from this window.
You can't let an opportunity like that go by - it's too good to miss.
Hardly a day goes by when I don't think about her.

meanings.definition: to follow something or be shown the way by something:
examples: I'm sorry, madam, but we have to go by the rules.

meanings.definition: to base an opinion, decision, or judgment on something:
examples: What do you go by when you're deciding whether or not to employ someone?
Going by what she said yesterday, I would say she's about to resign.
If past experience is anything to go by, he'll completely ignore our suggestions and then change his mind at the last minute.

meanings.definition: to follow or use information provided by something or someone:
examples: Don’t go by what she says – she’s always wrong.

meanings.definition: to be forgotten or not used:
examples: Does this mean our holiday plans will have to go by the board?

meanings.definition: to do things exactly as the rules say they should be done:
examples: This TV police officer is a maverick who doesn't go by the book.
My lawyer always goes strictly by the book.

go-by-the-name-of.name: go by the name of something

meanings.definition: to give yourself a name that is not your real name:
examples: In the business world he goes by the name of J. Walter Fortune.
I was introduced to our tour guide, who goes by the name of Bertha and dresses in period clothing for tours of the house.
The protagonist is a young actor who goes by the name of Al.
John Smith, who also goes by the name of Taylor, is accused of stealing the car on the night of June 5th.

meanings.definition: to stay in a tent on holiday:
examples: We used to go camping in Spain when I was a child.
I remember the first time I went camping.

go-cap-in-hand-to.name: go cap in hand to someone

meanings.definition: to ask someone in a polite and sincere way for something, especially money or to be forgiven
If someone goes cold turkey, they completely and suddenly stop taking a drug or other substance that they depend on. :
examples: Going cold turkey may cause serious withdrawal symptoms.
I've decided to go cold turkey on the cigarettes again.

meanings.definition: to not wear any underwear
to become mentally ill:
examples: For a long time, I honestly thought that I was going crazy.
Physical symptoms include shortness of breath, dizziness, heart palpitations, fear of dying or going crazy.

meanings.definition: to behave in an uncontrolled way, especially because you are feeling strong emotions:
examples: When she arrived on stage, the crowd screamed and went crazy.
I went crazy in the shops buying loads of vintage stuff.

meanings.definition: (of things) to grow or change very quickly and in a way that cannot easily be controlled :
examples: The tomatoes in the greenhouse are going crazy.
The prices on these antiques have gone crazy.

meanings.definition: to go to a place where people dance for entertainment:
examples: We went dancing at a club.
After dinner, he said that he wanted to go dancing.

meanings.definition: to stop all activities or communication, especially temporarily but for a fairly long period: (of a spy or secret agent) to stop communicating for a period of time with the people you are secretly working for:
examples: Theatres have gone dark, and arts groups have disbanded.
Two of the company's factories will go dark by mid-December.
In the wake of the attacks, TV networks went dark.
The campaign had to go dark in August to save money for a flurry of ads to run just before the debates.
She was undercover and thought the gang were onto her, so she went dark.

meanings.definition: If a piece of equipment goes dead, it stops working:
examples: The phone suddenly went dead.
The satellite's communications system went dead soon after reaching orbit.

meanings.definition: to move down to a lower level or place:
examples: He went down on his knees and begged for forgiveness.
The plane went down (= fell to the ground because of an accident, bomb, etc.) ten minutes after take-off.
Everyone took to the lifeboats when the ship started to go down (= sink).
Could I have a glass of water to help these pills go down (= to help me swallow them)?

meanings.definition: to reach or go as far as:
examples: Its roots can go down three metres.
This path goes down to the river.
Go down to (= read as far as) the bottom of the page.

meanings.definition: When the sun goes down, it seems to move down in the sky until it cannot be seen any more:
examples: On summer evenings we would sit on the veranda and watch the sun go down.
In December the sun goes down at four in the afternoon.

meanings.definition: to be reduced in price, value, amount, quality, level, or size:
examples: The temperature went down to minus ten last night.
The company's shares went down 7p to 53p.
The swelling's gone down but there's still a lot of bruising.
He went down in my estimation when he started trying to be a singer as well as an actor.

meanings.definition: to be remembered or recorded in a particular way:
examples: This will go down as a day that changed everything.
Hurricane Katrina will go down in the record books as the costliest storm ever faced by insurers.
He came up with an ad campaign that will go down in history.

meanings.definition: to get a particular type of reaction:
examples: "I told him I didn't like it." "And how did that go down?"
The joke didn't go down very well (= people did not find it funny).

meanings.definition: to lose or be defeated:
examples: England's unbeaten run of ten games ended last night when they went down 4–2 to France.
Dictators rarely go down without a fight.

meanings.definition: If a football team goes down, it drops to a lower division (= group of teams who play each other):
examples: At the end of the season, the three teams at the bottom go down.

meanings.definition: to be put in prison:
examples: She went down for three years for her part in the robbery.
He could go down for that.

meanings.definition: If a computer system goes down, it stops working:
examples: The battery should prevent the computer system from going down in the event of a power cut.

meanings.definition: If an event such as a crime or a deal goes down, it happens:
examples: Nobody really knows what went down that night.
I tried to tell Tyrell what was going down, but he wouldn't listen.

meanings.definition: If you go down from a college or university, especially Oxford University or Cambridge University, you leave either permanently or on holiday.
to become less in amount, value, etc.:
examples: The company's shares went down 7p to 53p.

meanings.definition: if a computer system goes down, it stops working:
examples: The battery should prevent the computer system from going down in the event of a power cut.

meanings.definition: to be remembered or recorded in a particular way:
examples: Hurricane Katrina will go down as one of the worst storms of this century.
He doesn't want to go down in the record books as the guy who walked away from his main responsibility.

meanings.definition: to be remembered as an important event, person, etc.:
examples: Quite whether he will go down in the annals of American history as a great leader remains to be seen.
The story of Molly the chicken went down in the annals of our family history.

go-down-like-a-lead-balloon.name: go down like a lead balloon

meanings.definition: If something that you say or show to people goes down like a lead balloon, they do not like it at all:
examples: My joke about the alcoholic went down like a lead balloon.

meanings.definition: to use the tongue and lips to touch someone's sexual organs in order to give pleasure
to continue to fight or to make a strong, determined effort even though you are likely to fail or lose:
examples: They beat us in the end, but we went down swinging.

meanings.definition: If work or money goes down the gurgler, it is wasted:
examples: So say he gives up his training, that's four thousand dollars down the gurgler.

meanings.definition: to fail or to be lost or destroyed:
examples: We don't want to see our business go down the pan.

meanings.definition: to fail completely:
examples: If business doesn't pick up soon, the company will go down the tubes.

meanings.definition: If food or drink goes down the wrong way, it goes down the wrong tube in your throat and causes you to cough or stop breathing for a short time.
to start to suffer from an infectious disease:
examples: Half of Martha's class has gone down with flu.

meanings.definition: to gradually become worse:
examples: After his wife died, his health started to go downhill.

meanings.definition: to agree to share the cost of something, especially a meal
to not take or use too much of something: to treat someone in a gentle way and not criticize them or punish them:
examples: Go easy on/with the cream - I haven't had any yet.
Go easy on the new students.

meanings.definition: to treat someone in a gentle way, esp. when you want to be or should be more severe:
examples: Do you think judges should go easy on criminals if they're teenagers?

meanings.definition: to not take or use too much of something:
examples: The doctor told me to go easy on the spicy food for a while.

meanings.definition: to be very successful in the future:
examples: She's a very talented writer - I'm sure she'll go far.

meanings.definition: used when you tell someone a fact and you then want to say that the fact is surprising, strange or stupid:
examples: It's a terrible movie and it made $200 million. Go figure!

meanings.definition: a children's card game in which players try to collect cards with particular values by asking for them from other players or taking them from a pile
used to tell someone who is being annoying to go away
to risk everything in the hope of having great success
to do anything you have to in order to get something:
examples: "I'm thinking of applying for that job." "Go for it!"

meanings.definition: infml to do what you need to do without additional thought:
examples: If you want it, then stop worrying about it and go for it.

meanings.definition: to attack someone:
examples: Their dog had to be put to sleep after it went for the postwoman.

meanings.definition: to choose something:
examples: Instead of butter, I always go for margarine or a low-fat spread.

meanings.definition: to like or admire:
examples: I don't go for war films in a big way (= very much).
What sort of men do you go for (= are you attracted to)?

meanings.definition: to try to have or achieve something:
examples: She tripped me as I went for the ball.
The Russian relay team will again be going for the gold medal at the Olympic Games.

meanings.definition: If something goes for a certain amount of money, it is sold for that amount:
examples: The painting is expected to go for at least a million dollars.

meanings.definition: If you go for something to eat or drink, you go to a restaurant, bar, etc. where you can eat or drink it. :
examples: Shall we go for a coffee?
Jay and I went for a curry last night.

meanings.definition: to try to achieve a goal, or try to attract someone's romantic interest:
examples: He’ll be going for his third straight Olympic gold medal in the 200-meter dash.

meanings.definition: to choose something or someone:
examples: Offered the choice between a higher salary and more vacation time, I know which one I’d go for.
He can't even count on all the voters who went for him the last time.

meanings.definition: to like or admire something:
examples: I don’t go for action movies or romances.

meanings.definition: to try to have or achieve something:
examples: The President said that he wouldn't go for such a plan if it meant he had to cut Medicare.

meanings.definition: if something goes for a certain amount of money, it is sold for that amount:
examples: Cheap bottles of vodka that go for less than $2 apiece.

meanings.definition: to make a serious effort to defeat someone, usually by criticizing or harming them in a cruel way:
examples: Cunningham went straight for the jugular, telling him that his work was a complete disaster.

meanings.definition: If a situation goes from bad to worse, it was difficult and unpleasant, and is becoming even more so:
examples: Things have gone from bad to worse.

meanings.definition: to become even more difficult or unpleasant:
examples: Things went from bad to worse in the second game when we lost 38-0.

meanings.definition: to gradually become more successful:
examples: The firm's gone from strength to strength since the new factory was built.

meanings.definition: If you go or take something further, you take it to a more advanced stage:
examples: Before we go any further with the project, I think we should make sure that there's enough money to fund it.

meanings.definition: If a recording of a popular song, or of a collection of popular songs, goes gold, it sells a large number of copies.
to go fast or successfully:
examples: For the first 400 metres he was going great guns, but then he fell and that lost him the race.

meanings.definition: to do more to protect nature and the environment:
examples: The Chancellor proposed a crackdown on car and plane emissions, and the introduction of tax incentives to go green.

This isn't the only sporting venue going green this year.
The pressure is mounting on small companies to go green.
There have to be financial incentives for average consumers who are going green.

meanings.definition: to divide the cost of something with someone:
examples: Shall we go halves on a bottle of champagne?

go-hand-in-hand-with.name: go hand in hand with something

meanings.definition: If something goes hand in hand with something else, it is closely related to it and happens at the same time as it or as a result of it:
examples: Prosperity goes hand in hand with investment.

meanings.definition: You say that someone can go hang (himself or herself) if you do not care what that person says or does about something:
examples: If she's expecting the report by tomorrow, she can go hang.

meanings.definition: to stop working correctly:
examples: They told us later in the hospital that his heart had gone haywire.

meanings.definition: to become too excited and eager about something, often so that you do too much:
examples: There's no need to go hog wild just because it's Sarah's birthday - she won't want such a fuss.

meanings.definition: to enter a place:
examples: I looked through the window, but I didn't actually go in.

meanings.definition: If the sun goes in, it becomes hidden from view by clouds.
If a fact or piece of information goes in, you understand it or remember it:
examples: No matter how many times you tell him something, it never seems to go in.

meanings.definition: to do something regularly, or to enjoy something:
examples: I've never really gone in for classical music, but I love jazz.

meanings.definition: to take part in a competition:
examples: Are you planning to go in for the 100 metres race?

meanings.definition: to do something regularly, or to enjoy something:
examples: I’ve never gone in for spending all day at the beach.

meanings.definition: to be involved in an activity that involves others:
examples: He bought a jet for personal use, inviting three friends to go in on it.

meanings.definition: to be involved in an activity that involves others:
examples: He bought a jet for personal use, inviting three friends to go in on it.

go-in-one-ear-and-out-the-other.name: go in one ear and out the other

meanings.definition: If you say that something you hear goes in one ear and out the other, you mean you quickly forget it:
examples: If I have to listen to something I don't understand, it just goes in one ear and out the other.

meanings.definition: to be heard but immediately forgotten:
examples: You can give her advice, but it just goes in one ear and out the other.

meanings.definition: to become less in amount, importance, quality, or strength:
examples: The economy has gone into a decline.

meanings.definition: If a person goes into a decline, they start to become physically or mentally weaker:
examples: She seemed to be recovering and then she went into a decline.

meanings.definition: If a company goes into administration because it cannot pay its debts, it is allowed to start the formal process of making changes to its organization to try to avoid having to close its business and sell the things it owns:
examples: The company announced last week it had gone into administration, blaming a drop in demand.
The club went into administration yesterday.

meanings.definition: to tell or include all the facts about something:
examples: I won't go into detail over the phone, but I've been having a few health problems recently.
He said he'd been having difficulties at work but he didn't go into detail.
She was asked about the incident but declined to go into detail.

He then went into detail about the project, as promised.

meanings.definition: to increase or succeed very quickly or to be in a state of extreme activity:
examples: Prices have gone into orbit this year.

meanings.definition: If a situation goes into reverse, it becomes the opposite of what it was before:
examples: The trend towards home ownership has gone into reverse.

meanings.definition: to express very great enthusiasm and admiration for something:
examples: She went into rhapsodies over/about the chocolate cake.

meanings.definition: to start doing a particular type of work:
examples: My son's planning to go into journalism.
She's decided to go into business as a freelance computer programmer.

meanings.definition: to start an activity, or start to be in a particular state or condition:
examples: The drug is still being tested and will not go into commercial production for at least two years.
How many companies have gone into liquidation/receivership during the current recession?
Repeated death threats have forced them to go into hiding.
Her baby was born three hours after she went into labour.
Some of the fans seemed to go into a trance when she appeared on stage.

meanings.definition: to discuss, examine, describe, or explain something in a detailed or careful way:
examples: This is the first book to go into her personal life as well as her work.
I'd rather not go into that now. Can we discuss it later?
I'm unable to go into details at this stage because I still have very little information about how the accident happened.
The company won't go into detail about its plans for the future.

meanings.definition: If time, money, or effort goes into a product or activity, it is used when producing or doing it:
examples: A considerable amount of time and effort has gone into this exhibition.

meanings.definition: If a vehicle goes into something such as a tree or a wall, it hits it:
examples: Their car was travelling at 50 miles an hour when it went into the tree.

meanings.definition: to discuss, describe, or explain something, esp. in a detailed or careful way:
examples: This is the first book to go into her personal life as well as her work.

meanings.definition: to start doing a particular type of work:
examples: My son's planning to go into journalism.
She's decided to go into business as a freelance computer programmer.

meanings.definition: to discuss, examine, or explain something in a detailed or careful way:
examples: The company has gone into detail about the prospects for each division.

meanings.definition: if time, money,la or effort goes into a product or activity, it is used when producing or doing it:
examples: A considerable amount of time and effort has gone into this marketing campaign.

meanings.definition: to become a priest:
examples: He was in his thirties when he decided to enter the church.

meanings.definition: to do something without other people:
examples: He's decided to leave the band and go it alone as a singer.

meanings.definition: to decide to do something by yourself, without help from other people:
examples: I decided to go it alone and set up my own business at home.

meanings.definition: to go wrong or stop working correctly:
examples: The story is about a business exec whose life goes kerflooey after his company fires him.
After that things went all kerfluey.
All their theories went kerflooey in the face of these new findings.
Her being there made the whole night go all kerflooey.
Last year it felt like everything went kerflooey.

meanings.definition: to move very quickly:
examples: His new car goes like a bomb.

meanings.definition: If a new system, especially a computer system, goes live, it starts to operate:
examples: Our new payments system will go live at the beginning of next month.
Our first public forum goes live next month and we will be monitoring its use.
The product, which is scheduled to go live next spring, offers improved reliability and flexibility.
A beta version of the app has now gone live.
Our new website will go live in a few days' time.

meanings.definition: If a person who is in a foreign country goes native, they begin to live and/or dress like the people who live there.
to become extremely angry:
examples: My sister will go nuts when she finds out I crashed her car.

meanings.definition: If a light or a machine goes off, it stops working:
examples: The lights went off in several villages because of the storm.

meanings.definition: If a bomb goes off, it explodes:
examples: The bomb went off at midday.

meanings.definition: If a gun goes off, it fires:
examples: His gun went off accidentally.

meanings.definition: If food or drink goes off, it is not good to eat or drink any more because it is too old:
examples: This bacon smells a bit funny - do you think it's gone off?

meanings.definition: If a warning device goes off, it starts to ring loudly or make a loud noise:
examples: The alarm should go off automatically as soon as smoke is detected.

meanings.definition: to leave a place and go somewhere else:
examples: She's gone off on holiday with Tony.

meanings.definition: to happen in a particular way:
examples: The protest march went off peacefully.

meanings.definition: to become worse in quality:
examples: That paper's really gone off since they got that new editor.

meanings.definition: to stop liking or being interested in someone or something:
examples: I went off beefburgers after I got food poisoning from a takeaway.
I went off Peter when he said those dreadful things about Clare.

meanings.definition: to explode, or to fire bullets:
examples: The deer ran away just before the hunter’s gun went off.

meanings.definition: If a special signal or an electronic device goes off, it warns people that there is danger or that something is wrong:
examples: What do they do if the metal detector goes off?

meanings.definition: to suddenly start talking or thinking about a completely new subject:
examples: It's hard to get a firm decision out of him - he's always going off on a tangent.

meanings.definition: to suddenly become very angry and start shouting or behaving violently:
examples: He went off on one because he thought I was threatening his dog.

meanings.definition: to lose interest or become less urgent:
examples: They were really excited about the project, but now they seem to have gone off the boil.

meanings.definition: to get very angry about something or lose control of yourself
to start behaving in a way that is not generally acceptable, especially dishonestly or illegally:
examples: He went off the rails in his first year at university.

meanings.definition: If a party or event goes off with a bang, it is very exciting and successful.
to leave a wife, husband, or partner in order to have a sexual or romantic relationship with someone else:
examples: Did you know that Hugh had gone off with his sister-in-law?

meanings.definition: to take something without getting permission from the owner first:
examples: I wish you'd stop going off with my car without asking me beforehand.

meanings.definition: to do something different to what is normal or expected:
examples: The presenter went off-piste from the script, with hilarious consequences.

meanings.definition: to happen:
examples: I'm sure we never hear about a lot of what goes on in government.

meanings.definition: to continue:
examples: Please go on with what you're doing and don't let us interrupt you.
We really can't go on living like this - we'll have to find a bigger house.
If you go on (= continue behaving) like this, you won't have any friends left at all.

meanings.definition: to move to the next thing or stage:
examples: She admitted her company's responsibility for the disaster and went on to explain how compensation would be paid to the victims.

meanings.definition: to start operating:
examples: The spotlights go on automatically when an intruder is detected in the garden.

meanings.definition: to start talking again after a pause:
examples: She paused to have a sip of coffee and then went on with her account of the accident.
"What I want more than anything else," he went on, "is a house in the country with a large garden for the children to play in."

meanings.definition: something that you say to encourage someone to say or do something:
examples: Go on, what happened next?

meanings.definition: to talk in an annoying way about something for a long time:
examples: He went on and on until I finally interrupted him and told him I had to go.
I just wish he'd stop going on about how brilliant his daughter is.
Mrs Spriggs certainly goes on, doesn't she?
I'm very fond of Tom, but he does go on a bit.
I wish you'd stop going on at me (= criticizing me repeatedly) about my haircut.

meanings.definition: used when encouraging someone to do something:
examples: Go on, have another drink.
"I don't really feel like seeing a film tonight." "Oh go on. We haven't been to the cinema for ages."

meanings.definition: something that you say in order to agree to do or allow something that you did not want to do or to allow before:
examples: "Are you sure you don't want another slice of cake?" "Oh go on then, but just a small one."

meanings.definition: to continue or pass:

As the evening went on, it became clear that we should never have agreed to see each other again.

meanings.definition: to use a piece of information in order to help you discover or understand something:
examples: I'm only going on what I overheard him saying to Chris, but I think he's planning to leave next month.

meanings.definition: to continue:
examples: I won’t go on working in this job forever.
Go on, tell me what happened next.
He could go on and on (= continue talking for a long time) about his adventures.

meanings.definition: to talk about something for a long time, often in an annoying way:
examples: Everyone at school keeps going on about how amazing she is.

meanings.definition: to travel somewhere and do something that is unusual, exciting, and possibly dangerous:
examples: They went on an adventure hunting for treasure in the western hills.

meanings.definition: If you go on record or if you are on record as saying something, you say it publicly and officially and it is written down.
to start to strike:
examples: All 2,500 employees went on strike in protest at the decision to close the factory.

meanings.definition: to be sold at an auction (= public sale)
to become an actor:
examples: At the age of ten, he decided that he wanted to go on the stage.

meanings.definition: to do something that is more advanced or more generous than someone else:
examples: I gave her a card, but my brother went one better and bought her a present.

meanings.definition: to leave a room or building, especially in order to do something for entertainment:
examples: Please close the door as you go out.

meanings.definition: to have a romantic and usually sexual relationship with someone:

meanings.definition: If the tide goes out, it moves back and covers less of the beach.

meanings.definition: to lose when you are playing in a sports competition, so that you must stop playing in the competition:

meanings.definition: to have a romantic relationship, esp. one that includes going places together:
examples: We’ve been going out for five months.

meanings.definition: (of the ocean tide) to be flowing to a lower level:

meanings.definition: If a quality, principle, or idea goes out of the window, it does not exist any more:

meanings.definition: to try to become part of a sports team:
examples: Unable to play ball with his hand in a cast, he went out for track.

meanings.definition: to try to become part of a sports team:
examples: Unable to play ball with his hand in a cast, he went out for track.

meanings.definition: to go to sleep very quickly or to become unconscious very quickly
to try very hard to do something, especially for someone else:

meanings.definition: to try especially hard to do something good or helpful:

meanings.definition: If your thoughts or sympathies go out to someone in a difficult or sad situation, you think of that person and feel sorry for them:
examples: Our deepest sympathies go out to her husband and children.

meanings.definition: to study or explain something:

meanings.definition: to be received in a particular way:

meanings.definition: to examine or look at something in a careful or detailed way:
examples: Remember to go over your essay to check for grammar and spelling mistakes.

meanings.definition: to study or explain something again:

meanings.definition: to examine or look at something in a careful or detailed way:
examples: I've gone over the problem several times, but I can't think of a solution.

meanings.definition: to speak to or ask permission from someone who has more authority than the person who you would normally go to in that situation: to be too difficult or strange for someone to understand:

meanings.definition: to change to something new or to a new way of doing things:
examples: Many firms are going over to new technologies.

meanings.definition: to change to a different person speaking or a different place during a television or radio programme:
examples: We're now going over to Kate Smith speaking live from Baghdad.

meanings.definition: to change to something new or to a new way of doing things:
examples: Many firms are going over to new technologies.

go-over-to-the-dark-side.name: go over to the dark side

meanings.definition: to start to behave in a way that is evil or harmful:
examples: I wrote about a doctor who had gone over to the dark side and was promoting unproven fad diets.

meanings.definition: to do something too much, or to be too excited or eager about something:
examples: I don't think there'll be more than six people eating, so I wouldn't go overboard with the food.

meanings.definition: to do or say too much because you are so enthusiastic:

meanings.definition: If a plan goes pear-shaped, it fails:
examples: We'd planned to go away for the weekend, but it all went pear-shaped.

meanings.definition: to be likely to be successful in the future:

meanings.definition: a rude way of telling someone to go away and stop annoying you:

meanings.definition: to explode:
examples: If I eat any more I'm going to go pop!

meanings.definition: to become very angry and do something violent:

meanings.definition: to pay for private health care or private education: of a public company, to become privately owned:

meanings.definition: to make something known that was secret before:
examples: We will not go public with the results until tomorrow.

meanings.definition: to make something known that was secret before:
examples: If the teacher goes public with her story, the school's reputation will be damaged.

meanings.definition: to become a company in which anyone can invest:

meanings.definition: to become a company in which anyone can invest:

meanings.definition: If something goes right, it is successful or happens in a way that you hoped it would:

meanings.definition: to start behaving in a way that is not normal or expected, especially by leaving your group and doing something dangerous:

meanings.definition: to spin like a wheel
If there is enough of something to go round, there is enough for everyone in a group of people:
examples: Are there enough pencils to go round?

meanings.definition: to spend your time behaving in the stated way:
examples: You can't go round being rude to people.

meanings.definition: to visit someone in their home:
examples: I'm just going round to Martha's for half an hour.

meanings.definition: to go or be given from one person to another, or to move from one place to another:
examples: A nasty flu bug is going round (the school) at the moment.

meanings.definition: to travel to all, or the main, parts of a place that you are visiting in order to find out what it is like or to learn about it:

meanings.definition: to divide something such as a cost between you:

meanings.definition: to become much worse:

meanings.definition: If a man goes stag to an event, he goes without a partner.

meanings.definition: to manage to continue until the end of a competition

used to tell someone to go away

meanings.definition: to be given or sold to someone:

meanings.definition: to have an election:

to become much worse in quality or character:

meanings.definition: to increase:

meanings.definition: to reach as far as something:

examples: The two children both made a grab for the same cake.

meanings.definition: to take or take hold of something or someone suddenly:
examples: I grabbed the rope and pulled myself out of the water.
We’d better get there early, or someone else will grab the best seats (= take them first).
infml Let’s grab a sandwich (= get it and eat it quickly) before we leave.

meanings.definition: to try to get hold of someone or something quickly, with your hand
a bag or container containing a mixture of small objects such as toys, often to be taken out without being seen, as a game :
examples: The children will be greeted with baseball caps and cards, T-shirts, and grab bags.

meanings.definition: a mixed collection of things that may not go particularly well together:
examples: The concert's second half was a bit of a grab bag.
What we are likely to see is the usual grab bag of half thought-out policies.

meanings.definition: a bag or container holding necessary supplies such as food to last for a few days, for use in an emergency:
examples: They drew up a list of essential items to put in an emergency grab bag in case of a hurricane.

meanings.definition: any mixed collection of things, some of which may not be very attractive or useful:
examples: The musical was a grab bag of old, tired songs and a few gems.

meanings.definition: a bar attached to a wall that people can hold to help them get up or down somewhere or avoid falling:
examples: A simple grab rail placed by a bath or toilet can make a considerable difference to someone with limited mobility.

meanings.definition: to attract someone's attention:
examples: You must grab the reader's attention from the first sentence.
We need an image that will really grab people's attention.
It's one of many commercial operators desperate to grab our attention.
The use of bold, constrasting colours is designed to grab our attention.
The sudden shouting across the street certainly grabbed my attention.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is ready for you to take quickly when you do not have much time, or to describe the activity of taking things quickly like this:
examples: They sell grab-and-go meals ranging from burritos to Asian chicken salad.
I am building up a grab and go bag in the event of an emergency when I need to leave the area quickly.
The drink container is a new packaging concept designed for the grab-and-go generation.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         grab
a device with two parts that open and close on the end, used for taking hold of or picking up things:
examples: I added a metal pot grabber to my kit to grab and lift cans and metal pots off the fire.

meanings.definition: someone who takes an opportunity to get, use, or enjoy something quickly:

In every era the power grabbers promise safety from what people most fear.

meanings.definition: something or someone who makes you pay attention:

meanings.definition: getting or taking a lot of the stated thing:

meanings.definition: wanting to or designed to attract attention:

meanings.definition: a quality of moving in a smooth, relaxed, and attractive way:
examples: Joanna has natural grace and elegance.

meanings.definition: the quality of being pleasantly polite, or a willingness to be fair and honest:
examples: They accepted their defeat with good grace.

meanings.definition: approval or kindness, especially (in the Christian religion) that is freely given by God to all humans:
examples: Betty believed that it was through divine grace that her husband had recovered from his illness.

meanings.definition: a prayer said by Christians before a meal to thank God for the food:
examples: The children always say grace at dinnertime.

meanings.definition: a period of time left or allowed before something happens or before something must be done:
examples: The exams have been postponed, so the students have a few days' grace before they start.

meanings.definition: to be in a place, on a thing etc. and make it look more attractive:
examples: Her face has graced the covers of magazines across the world.

meanings.definition: simple beauty of movement or form:
examples: The skaters moved over the ice with effortless grace.

meanings.definition: the charming quality of being polite and pleasant, or a willingness to be fair and to forgive:

meanings.definition: a prayer of thanks to God that is said before and sometimes after a meal:
examples: Before we eat, I want to ask Cory to say grace.

meanings.definition: Grace is also approval or protection given by God:
examples: By the grace of God, I hope to live for many years.

meanings.definition: an added period of time allowed before something must be done or paid:
examples: The landlord gave us a week’s grace to pay the rent.

meanings.definition: extra time after the normal date that a payment should be made, work should be finished, etc. during which there is no punishment for being late:

meanings.definition: a musical note printed in smaller size to show that it is not essential to the music, but is used just for a beautiful effect:

meanings.definition: a small addition to make something more beautiful or interesting:

meanings.definition: extra time you are given to pay money you owe without losing something or paying an additional amount:

meanings.definition: difficult or unpleasant activity that is tiring or repeated too often:
examples: Karen came to the hotel for a rest from the daily grind.

meanings.definition: a difficult or boring activity that needs a lot of effort:
examples: He recalls the grind of working his day job and then in a bar at night.

meanings.definition: to treat someone so badly for such a long time that they are no longer able to fight back:
examples: Ground down by years of abuse, she did not have the confidence to leave him.

meanings.definition: to annoy someone:
examples: What really grinds my gears is when people talk behind your back.

meanings.definition: to press something hard into something else using a twisting movement:
examples: Sara angrily ground her cigarette into the ashtray.

meanings.definition: to produce the same thing, especially a boring thing, again and again:
examples: The band ground out the same tunes it had been playing for 20 years.

to stop or no longer work well:

meanings.definition: to make a noise by rubbing your teeth together:

examples: Students take science courses, such as human gross anatomy, neurobiology, and pathology.

meanings.definition: the total amount of a person's or organization's income in a one-year period before tax is paid on it:

meanings.definition: in some countries, especially in the past, an expression used to refer to some criminal sexual offences, especially sexual activity between men when this was illegal, or sexual offences against children:
examples: He was found guilty of a string of offences of gross indecency and sexual assault.

meanings.definition: money received in interest on bank accounts or investments before tax is paid on it:

meanings.definition: the total value of an investment without allowing for any loss in worth, especially over time:

meanings.definition: the total amount of a company’s losses from its different activities in a particular period, even if it makes a profit on some of these activities:
examples: Today the company reported a gross loss of $17.15 bn for the second quarter.

meanings.definition: a company’s profit from selling goods or services in a particular period before costs not directly related to producing them are taken away. Gross margin is often shown as a percentage of sales:
examples: The software company has $30 million in revenues, 80% gross margin, and 5% pretax profit.

meanings.definition: dishonest, unacceptable, and often illegal behaviour, especially when this relates to a person's employment (= work):

meanings.definition: in ice hockey, a penalty (= punishment) given to a player for breaking the rules in a way that is very serious, such as causing injury to another player or official, and for which the player must leave the game and not return:
examples: He received a gross misconduct penalty for hitting the opponent on the head with his stick.

meanings.definition: unacceptable behaviour by an employee as a result of which they will probably lose their job:

meanings.definition: a serious lack of care or attention towards a person or thing that you are responsible for:

meanings.definition: using unusual methods to create or get attention for your ideas, art, products, etc., usually ones that cost little money and involve using public spaces:

A new work by the "guerrilla" artist known as Banksy has appeared.

meanings.definition: a member of an unofficial military group that is trying to change the government by making sudden, unexpected attacks on the official army forces:
examples: guerrilla warfare

meanings.definition: the activity of growing plants without permission on land that belongs to someone else or on public land, with the aim of improving the environment or producing vegetables or flowers for people to use or enjoy
unusual methods of getting attention for a product or service, usually ones that cost little money and involve giving or showing things to people in public places:
examples: They are a design studio in Los Angeles specializing in guerrilla marketing, using street-art techniques to promote brands.
Uploading a video to YouTube is a relatively inexpensive form of guerrilla marketing.

meanings.definition: any form of marketing that is original, unusual, and not expensive:
examples: a guerrilla marketing campaign

meanings.definition: to give an answer to a particular question when you do not have all the facts and so cannot be certain if you are correct:
examples: I didn't know the answer, so I had to guess.
On the last question, she guessed right/wrong.
Guess when this was built.
I guessed (that) she was your sister.
She asked me to guess her age.
I guessed the total amount to be about £50,000.

meanings.definition: to give the correct answer or make the correct judgment:
examples: I bet you can't guess how old he is.
She guessed the answer on her first try.
"You have a new job, don't you?" "Yes, how did you guess?"

meanings.definition: an attempt to give the right answer when you are not certain if you are correct:
examples: Go on - have/make a guess.
Both teams made some wild guesses (= made without much thought), none of which were right.

meanings.definition: someone's opinion about something that is formed without any knowledge of the situation:
examples: "I wonder why she's not here." "My guess is that her car has broken down."

meanings.definition: to give an answer to a question when you do not have all the facts and so cannot be certain if you are right:
examples: I didn’t know the answer, so I had to guess.
He guessed (that) she was about 50.

meanings.definition: To guess can also mean to give the correct answer:
examples: She guessed the right answer.

meanings.definition: To guess also means to think or believe:
examples: My plane leaves in an hour, so I guess I’d better be going.
"Is he going to call you back?" "I guess so."

meanings.definition: an attempt to give the right answer when you are not certain if you are right:
examples: Go on, take a guess.

meanings.definition: Someone’s guess is also an opinion about something, formed without any knowledge of the situation:
examples: I don’t know why she’s late, but my guess is she got off at the wrong exit.

meanings.definition: to try to imagine something when you have little knowledge or experience of it:
examples: There are no photographs of him, so we can only guess at what he looked like.

meanings.definition: used before telling someone something interesting or surprising:
examples: Guess what? We won the game 4–0.
He called me that morning and said, "Guess what? Coral and I are getting back together."
I worked up the courage to talk to them and guess what? Making friends isn't so hard after all.
You forgot to call to tell us you got in safely? Well, guess what? You wouldn't have had cellphone service anyway up at the cabin.
This is the killer's DNA, and guess what? It matches our suspect.

meanings.definition: an approximate calculation of the size or amount of something when you do not know all the facts:
examples: Current guesstimates are that the company's turnover will increase by six percent this year.

meanings.definition: a calculation of the size or amount of something when you do not know all the facts:
examples: Current guesstimates are that the company’s profits will increase by 10% this year.

meanings.definition: an approximate calculation of the size or amount of something:
examples: I would put potential sales at about 100,000, but that's only a guesstimate.

meanings.definition: the process of making a guess when you do not know all the facts:
examples: The projected sales figures are pure guesswork on our part.

meanings.definition: the process of making a guess when you do not know all the facts:
examples: She had to rely on pure guesswork in deciding how much food to order.

meanings.definition: a person who is staying with you, or a person you have invited to a social occasion, such as a party or a meal:
examples: 150 guests were invited to the wedding.
We have guests staying this weekend.
Is he on the guest list?
He is a paying guest (= he pays for the use of a room in someone's home).

meanings.definition: a person who is staying in a hotel:
examples: We would like to remind all our guests to leave their keys at reception before they depart.

meanings.definition: a person who is not a member of something such as a club or website, but is allowed to use it:
examples: Non-members may use club facilities as a guest for a small fee.
Please log in using your password, or click here to continue as a guest.

meanings.definition: a person, such as an entertainer, who has been invited to appear on a television or radio programme, or to help perform or produce something:
examples: Our special guest on the programme tonight is Robert de Niro.
Madonna made a guest appearance at the concert.
Simon Rattle will be the guest conductor with the London Symphony Orchestra.

meanings.definition: something such as an animal that is living in a place, especially where it is not wanted:
examples: Warm weather is the ideal breeding ground for bacteria — an unwanted guest at any cookout or picnic.
Foreclosed houses around the country have been colonized by stray dogs, rats and other uninvited guests.

meanings.definition: If a person, especially an entertainer, guests on a programme or show, they are invited to appear or perform on it:
examples: He guests on their latest video.

meanings.definition: a person who is staying with you in your home, or a person whom you have invited to a social occasion, such as a party or a meal:
examples: dinner/wedding guests

meanings.definition: A person who is staying in a hotel is also called a guest.
If you are someone’s guest, that person is paying for you:
examples: Four senators and their families were flown to Martinique as guests of the oil company.

meanings.definition: a person who has been invited to a place:
examples: The factory owners treated us as honored guests.
The store opening featured several guest speakers from the local business community.

meanings.definition: a person who is staying in a hotel:
examples: We would like to remind all our guests to leave their keys at reception before they depart.

meanings.definition: a type of beer that is made by a different company from the one that normally supplies the beer in a bar, and is sold in the bar for a short time
a book in which people write their names and addresses when they have been staying at a hotel
a list of the people who are invited to an event or social occasion such as a party:
examples: I put her name on the guest list for one of our concerts.

meanings.definition: the most important person at a social occasion:
examples: The president was guest of honor at the dinner.

meanings.definition: the most important person at a social occasion:
examples: The prime minister was the guest of honour at the dinner.

meanings.definition: a bedroom in a house for visitors to sleep in
a person who lives and works in a foreign country for a limited period of time, usually doing low-paid and unskilled work
a person who is allowed by the government of another country to work in that country for a limited period:
examples: In most nations there are limitations on the rights of guest workers.

meanings.definition: to laugh loudly but briefly:
examples: Kruger guffawed as though Ray had told him a really funny joke.

help and advice about how to do something or about how to deal with problems connected with your work, education, or personal relationships:

careers guidance

meanings.definition: the process of directing the flight of a missile or rocket:
examples: a missile guidance system

meanings.definition: help and advice about how to do something or about how to deal with problems:
examples: She never got any guidance when she needed it.
The school district needs another guidance counselor to work with students (= a person employed to give help and advice to students).

meanings.definition: help and advice about how to do something or to deal with problems:
examples: The website offers guidance to employers on employment law.
The first chapter gives guidance on how to make the best use of existing staff.
Freelance staff have been brought in to help develop software systems under Chris's guidance.

meanings.definition: written information that a company gives about its probable financial results for a particular period, before the period has ended:
examples: to provide/give/issue guidance

meanings.definition: someone whose job is to help people choose a job or career
a book that gives you the most important information about a particular subject:
examples: a hotel/wine guide

meanings.definition: a guidebook:
examples: We recommend you buy a reputable guide to Spain before travelling there.

meanings.definition: something that helps you form an opinion or make a decision about something else:
examples: I never follow recipes exactly when I cook - I just use them as rough guides.

meanings.definition: a person whose job is showing a place or a particular route to visitors:
examples: We hired a guide to take us up into the mountains.
Our tour guide recommended some good places to eat in the area.

meanings.definition: a person or thing that influences what you do or think:
examples: Let your conscience be your guide.

meanings.definition: the screen on a television that shows you a list of all the programmes that are available and where and when they are broadcast:
examples: The guide allows you to browse scheduled programmes across time, date, and channel.

The remote control has a Guide button.

meanings.definition: to show someone how to do something difficult:
examples: Our lawyer guided us through the more complicated questions on the form.

meanings.definition: to show people around a place:
examples: The curator guided us through the gallery, pointing out the most famous paintings in the collection.
Samira gave us a guided tour of the city.

meanings.definition: to take someone somewhere or to show someone how to get somewhere:
examples: The shop assistant guided me to the shelf where the gardening books were displayed.
The runway lights guide the plane in to land.

meanings.definition: to take hold of part of someone's body, especially their arm, and take that person somewhere:
examples: He took my arm and guided me to the bar.

meanings.definition: to make something move in the direction in that you want it to go:
examples: The pilot guided the plane onto the runway.
She guided the child's head and arms into the T-shirt.

meanings.definition: to influence someone's behaviour:
examples: Trust your own judgment and don't be guided by what anyone else thinks.

meanings.definition: a girl between ten and 14 years old who is a member of the Guides organization

meanings.definition: the standard unit of money used in the Netherlands before the introduction of the euro

clever but sometimes dishonest behaviour that you use to deceive someone:
examples: The president will need to use all her political guile to stay in power.
He is a simple man, totally lacking in guile.

meanings.definition: the practice of deceiving people or using other dishonest methods to achieve your aims, or the ability to deceive people for this purpose:
examples: He is a simple, honest man, totally lacking in guile.

meanings.definition: using cleverness in order to deceive someone or get what you want:
examples: We could see that John's guileful smile and flattering talk were a disguise, and that he was really looking for a way to take advantage of the situation.
I don't think she is all that guileful; she'll be straightforward with you about her plans.

meanings.definition: in a way that uses cleverness in order to deceive someone or get what you want:
examples: The soldiers guilefully lured the invading army into the forest and then surrounded them.
The president guilefully waited until the final year of her term to announce the relief package so that voters would remember it when she ran for re-election.

meanings.definition: honest, not able to deceive:
examples: She regarded him with wide, guileless blue eyes.

meanings.definition: honest and direct:
examples: He was completely guileless and trusting.

meanings.definition: in an honest way, with no effort to deceive anyone or get something you want:
examples: We guilelessly announced to the police everything we knew, not realizing that we were suspects.
She hadn't expected to win the tournament and could only be guilelessly humble when she did.

meanings.definition: a condition in which the immune system attacks part of the nervous system, starting in the nerves of the feet and hands, resulting in weak muscles, loss of feeling and possible paralysis (= inability to move):
examples: Most patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome recover well but some never fully regain muscle strength.

meanings.definition: each of the pair of punctuation marks << and >> used in French and some other languages around a word or phrase to show that someone else has written or said it
a black and white sea bird with a long, narrow beak that lives in northern parts of the world
a device, invented in France, consisting of a sharp blade in a tall frame, used in the past for killing criminals by cutting off their heads:

meanings.definition: a device with a long sharp blade that is used for cutting large quantities of paper

meanings.definition: a feeling of worry or unhappiness that you have because you have done something wrong, such as causing harm to another person:
examples: He suffered such feelings of guilt over leaving his children.
She remembered with a pang of guilt that she hadn't called her mother.

meanings.definition: the fact of having done something wrong or committed a crime:
examples: Both suspects admitted their guilt to the police.
The prosecution's task in a case is to establish a person's guilt beyond any reasonable doubt.

meanings.definition: the fact or state of having done something wrong or committed a crime:
examples: In the US, people accused of a crime are presumed to be innocent until their guilt is proven.

meanings.definition: Guilt is also a feeling of anxiety or unhappiness that you have done something immoral or wrong, such as causing harm to another person:
examples: She was tormented by feelings of guilt after putting her mother in a nursing home.

meanings.definition: a very strong feeling of guilt that you cannot get rid of:
examples: She has a guilt complex about inheriting so much money.

meanings.definition: a strong feeling of guilt because of something you have done wrong or forgotten to do:
examples: I never call her and every time she calls me I have a guilt trip.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel guilty, usually in order to make them do something:
examples: He's just trying to guilt-trip you into paying him more.

meanings.definition: infml a strong feeling of having done something wrong in a particular situation:
examples: Hector is going through a major guilt trip over losing his job.

meanings.definition: allowing you to enjoy something without feeling unhappy that you are doing something bad:
examples: a guilt-free chocolate cake made without fat
The travel company offers guilt-free trips that won't damage the environment.

meanings.definition: feeling very guilty

past simple and past participle of 
        
         guilt-trip   informal

present participle of 
        
         guilt-trip   informal
a period of time when you experience a particular feeling strongly:
examples: She's been on a real power trip since she became the office manager.

Just the idea of being considered a celebrity was such an ego trip for her.

Becoming President is surely the ultimate power trip.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you feel guilty:
examples: "I don't know where your money is!" she exclaimed guiltily.

meanings.definition: a feeling of worry or unhappiness because you have done something wrong:
examples: Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

meanings.definition: the fact of being responsible for breaking a law:

meanings.definition: not responsible for doing something wrong or committing a crime
without feeling guilty, because you know or feel that you have not done anything wrong:

meanings.definition: feeling guilt:
examples: I feel so guilty about forgetting her birthday.

meanings.definition: responsible for breaking a law:

meanings.definition: If you feel guilty, you feel that you have done something wrong:
examples: I feel so guilty about forgetting your birthday.

meanings.definition: Someone who has a guilty conscience is unhappy because of something wrong that the person feels he or she has done.
responsible for doing something illegal that you have been accused of in court: used to admit that what someone has been accused of is true, often when you think this is not really bad:
examples: They were guilty as charged and fairly tried, and therefore justice was served.

meanings.definition: the appearance of someone or something, esp. when intended to deceive:
examples: The men who arrived in the guise of criminals were actually undercover police officers.

meanings.definition: someone who dresses up as a magical or frightening creature or as a character from a story on Halloween (= 31 October), and visits people's homes to ask for sweets or money:
examples: We've had ten guisers round so far.
Display this notice in your window if you don't want guisers.

meanings.definition: the activity of dressing up as magical or frightening creatures or as characters from a story on Halloween (= 31 October ), and visiting people's homes to ask for sweets or money:
examples: In Scotland we don't do "trick or treat"; we do guising.

meanings.definition: a musical instrument, usually made of wood, with six strings and a long neck, played with the fingers or a plectrum:
examples: He sat on the grass, strumming his guitar.
an acoustic guitar
an electric guitar

meanings.definition: a musical instrument with usually six strings and a flat back that is held on the knee or by a strap worn over the shoulder and played by moving the fingers or a small piece of plastic across the strings, or this instrument generally:
examples: an acoustic/electric guitar

meanings.definition: a person who plays the guitar:
examples: a classical/folk/rock guitarist

meanings.definition: a person who plays the guitar
a language spoken by many people from India, that is the state language of the Gujarat region
a person from the Gujarat region of India or a person who speaks Gujarati
a deep narrow valley with steep sides, especially one formed by fast-flowing water :
examples: At the head of the trail, he stopped to peer down into the gulch.
The storm carved out a gulch where the creek now flows.

meanings.definition: a narrow valley or channel with steep sides, made by a fast-flowing stream
used to describe something on a coat of arms (= a special shield or shield-shaped pattern that is the sign of a family, university, or city) that is red:
examples: Henry VII sometimes used a dragon gules and a greyhound argent.
His arms were gules three crescents or (= red with three gold crescents).

meanings.definition: a very large area of sea surrounded on three sides by a coast:
examples: the Gulf of Mexico

meanings.definition: a very large, deep hole in the ground
an important difference between the ideas, opinions, or situations of two groups of people:
examples: There is a widening gulf between the rich and the poor in our society.
It is hoped that the peace plan will bridge the gulf (= reduce the very large difference) between the government and the rebels.

meanings.definition: an area of sea surrounded on three sides by land:
examples: the Gulf of Mexico/the Gulf Coast
the Gulf Stream

meanings.definition: an important difference between two things or groups of people:
examples: There is a widening gulf between the rich and the poor.

meanings.definition: a kind of brown seaweed (= a plant that grows in the sea) that forms large masses on the surface of the sea:
examples: Floating masses of gulfweed in the Sargasso Sea were regarded as uncanny and dangerous by early sailors.

meanings.definition: a bird that lives near the coast with black and white or grey and white feathers
someone who is easily tricked or cheated:
examples: What a gull I've been!
Surely he's not such a gull that he would believe her ridiculous story.

meanings.definition: to trick or cheat someone:
examples: She was gulled by a smooth-talking con man.
They gulled him into buying something he didn't want or need.

meanings.definition: a large bird that is black or gray and white and that lives near the sea
the tube that food travels down in the body from the mouth to the stomach
the quality of being easily deceived or tricked, and too willing to believe everything that other people say:
examples: His arguments are aimed at the public's gullibility rather than their intelligence.
The couple asked not to be named because they were embarrassed at their gullibility.

meanings.definition: easily deceived or tricked, and too willing to believe everything that other people say:
examples: There are any number of miracle cures on the market for people gullible enough to buy them.

meanings.definition: easily deceived or tricked, and too willing to believe everything that other people say:
examples: a gullible young man

meanings.definition: in the way that shows you are easily deceived or tricked, or too willing to believe everything that people say:
examples: I can't believe that they have, gullibly, got themselves into this.

meanings.definition: a narrow valley or channel with steep sides, made by a fast-flowing stream:
examples: Gullies and ravines can swell with floodwaters after heavy rain.
The water has carved deep gullies through the soft limestone of the foothills.

meanings.definition: an artificial channel that is used to get rid of water that is not wanted:
examples: He grew up in a poor area, between a cemetery and a sewage gully.

meanings.definition: in cricket, a position of a fielder (= a player who tries to stop the other team from scoring by stopping or catching the ball) which is close to and just behind the batter (= the player trying to hit the ball) on the right side for a right-handed batter and on the left side for a left-handed batter:
examples: He took a fantastic catch at gully.
She cut the ball through the gully for four.

meanings.definition: in cricket, a player who fields (= tries to stop the other team from scoring by stopping or catching the ball) at the position of gully:
examples: When you have four slips and two gullies, the opposition is always likely to score a lot of fours.

meanings.definition: a channel cut by running water, which is usually dry except after heavy rain
a process in which soil, stone, etc. is gradually damaged and removed from the surface of the ground by the running water of a river, stream, etc., or the result of this action:
examples: Stretches of the valley have been carved up by gully erosion.

meanings.definition: to eat or drink food or liquid quickly by swallowing it in large amounts, or to make a swallowing movement because of fear, surprise, or excitement:

meanings.definition: to breathe in a large amount of air very quickly

examples: "I find this a very confusing conversation to have," he exclaimed, gulping.

meanings.definition: to eat or drink something quickly:
examples: He hardly has time to gulp down a piece of pizza.

meanings.definition: to try not to show that you are upset, usually by swallowing hard:
examples: She gulped back the tears.

meanings.definition: the ability to decide what is the best thing to do in a particular situation, and to do it with energy and determination:

a weapon that bullets or shells (= explosive containers) are fired from:

meanings.definition: in sport, a device that makes a very loud sudden noise as a signal to start a race:

to destroy the inside of a building completely, usually by fire:
examples: A fire gutted the bookshop last week.

meanings.definition: to remove the inside parts and contents of a building, usually so that it can be decorated in a completely new way
to remove the inner organs of an animal, especially in preparation for eating it:
examples: She gutted the fish and cut off their heads.

meanings.definition: the bowels or the stomach:
examples: I had a feeling of sickness deep in the gut.

meanings.definition: Your gut is also the front part of your body near the waist:
examples: He’d added a few extra pounds to his gut.

meanings.definition: The guts of a machine are its inner, necessary parts:
examples: The front panel was attached to the guts of the unit by three color-coded wires.

meanings.definition: coming from or having to do with your emotions, not from thought:
examples: My gut reaction is we’d better not get involved.

meanings.definition: to destroy or remove the inside parts of a building:

meanings.definition: a strong belief about someone or something that cannot completely be explained and does not have to be decided by reasoning:
examples: I have a gut feeling that the relationship won't last.

meanings.definition: a hard hit to the stomach:

meanings.definition: something that shocks and upsets you very much:

meanings.definition: something that badly damages or harms something or someone:
examples: There were other ways the company could have handled this without throwing a gut punch to suppliers.

meanings.definition: good for your gut (= the long tube in the body, through which food moves during the process of digesting food), especially for its microbiome (= the very small organisms that live in it):

meanings.definition: making you feel very upset or worried:

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you feel extremely sad, shocked, or upset:

meanings.definition: showing no courage:

meanings.definition: bravery and determination:

meanings.definition: in a way that is brave and determined:

meanings.definition: to drink quickly, eagerly, and usually in large amounts:
examples: He guzzled his beer and ordered another.

meanings.definition: to use large amounts of petrol very quickly:
examples: The car guzzles a gallon of gas every 15 miles.

meanings.definition: to drink or eat something eagerly or in large amounts:
examples: He sat in the shade, guzzling cold soda.
